Text: 'Some time ago, a website pointed out the dangers of public check-ins, which are online announcements of where you are. The website's message was clear: while you might think you are simply saying, "Hey, I’m at this place," you are also letting many people know your location – not all of whom you may want to meet. This highlighted the growing understanding that there can be negative aspects to the constant sharing that the internet encourages. The internet offers many chances to share every part of our lives with a global audience, which can seem exciting: wealth, fame, and more! So, we dive into the chaos of the internet, sharing personal stories, photos, and confessions. However, we often realize too late that the online world can be crowded and dangerous, leaving us feeling lost. This may sound discouraging, but there is hope. The future has been mapped out for us by early internet pioneers. In the beginning, they explored these online waters and identified the risks. They faced job losses, gained and lost friends, and dealt with the challenges of fame long before social media existed. These pioneers, known as the first bloggers, have already experienced what many of us are now facing. It is important to learn from their experiences. 

In January 1994, Justin Hall, a 19-year-old student, started posting on the World Wide Web, which was mostly used by graduate students, scientists, and a few talented teens. The web was created at CERN, a physics lab in Switzerland, to help researchers share their work. Hall saw a different opportunity: to share his life. He created a complex web of personal stories, photos, and art. In January 1996, he began a daily blog, attracting many readers who were fascinated by his adventurous use of this new medium. Hall's approach was simple: anyone who crossed his path could appear on his site, and no topic was off-limits. While some may see this as attention-seeking behavior, there was also a depth and beauty to his work that many would consider art. 

However, one day, visitors to Hall’s site found his homepage replaced by a single, emotional video titled Dark Night. He shared that he had fallen deeply in love, but when he wrote about it online, he was told, "either the blog goes, or I do." He felt that sharing his life online made people distrust him. The blog was removed, but the issue remains. Sharing online can be wonderful, but if you think that sharing your life will make people want to be around you, you may be disappointed. 

In 2002, Heather Armstrong, a young web worker in Los Angeles, had a blog called Dooce. Sometimes, she wrote about her job at a software company. One day, an anonymous coworker sent the link to her blog to all the vice presidents at her company, including some she had criticized, which led to her losing her job. Researchers who study online behavior have a term for this: the "online distribution effect," which describes the feeling that we can say things online that we would never say in person. However, the internet is not a separate reality where we can speak freely without consequences. Our online lives are connected to our real lives, and ignoring this can lead to serious mistakes. 

Armstrong's story had a happy ending. Although she was upset and stopped blogging for a few months, she eventually got married and restarted her blog, focusing on her new family. Today, she is a well-known "mommy blogger," and her writing supports her family. Once a symbol of the risks of online sharing, she has become skilled at revealing just enough about herself. Armstrong has learned an important lesson: while the internet allows us to say anything, that doesn’t mean we should.'

Text: 'Some scientists recently started a campaign to warn people about a low-budget film called What the Bleep Do We Know? This film mixes documentary and drama to suggest that there is much about our universe that we do not understand. How can any scientist disagree with that? Scientists can sometimes be arrogant, but even the most enthusiastic physicist would not claim to know everything about the universe. However, some scientists felt it was important to warn the public about the film, calling it everything from ‘atrocious’ to ‘very dangerous’. Clearly, this film was controversial. 

At first, I did not understand the fuss. Various scientists made harmless statements about how new discoveries were showing that the universe is stranger than we thought. It was only when the film discussed some of these discoveries that I began to see the concern – discoveries like the idea that water molecules can be influenced by thoughts. I had heard before about a Japanese researcher who claimed that the shape of a water molecule could change based on the thoughts of people nearby. However, the film only provided pictures of ice crystals that looked beautiful after being spoken to positively and ugly after being exposed to negative feelings. Many people find this kind of evidence convincing because it is simple and easy to understand. However, scientists typically respond with skepticism. 

I understand their point. The idea that water can be influenced by thoughts is fascinating and suggests new forces in the universe. But before we get too excited, we need solid proof that this effect is real. Beautiful pictures of crystals, while nice, are not enough. The real issue is that the film’s claims were not strange enough. For example, water molecules might have properties linked to a mysterious energy that drives the expansion of the universe. This idea is supported by decades of research from laboratories and observatories worldwide. 

In fact, discoveries are being made that confirm the universe is stranger than we ever imagined. Astronomers have discovered that the universe is made of an unknown type of matter and is driven by a mysterious force called ‘dark energy’. Additionally, scientists are making incredible discoveries on Earth. Neuroscientists have found that our awareness of events is delayed by about half a second, a delay we do not notice because our brains edit it out. Anthropologists believe they have found where modern humans originated and how they spread across the world. Some theorists even suggest links between life on Earth and the fundamental design of the universe. 

Despite what some may think, science is not close to being complete. In fact, we seem further from knowing everything than ever. Many natural phenomena may never be fully understood. The ideas of chaos and quantum uncertainty have shown that there are limits to what we can know. Some of the world’s leading physicists are trying to create a Theory of Everything, which would explain all the forces and particles in the universe with one equation. Overall, many of us believe that the universe can be described in one word: incredible.'

Text: "In simple terms, I find writing novels challenging, while writing short stories is a joy. If writing novels is like planting a forest, then writing short stories is like planting a garden. Both processes complement each other, creating a landscape I cherish. The trees provide shade, and the wind rustles the leaves, which can turn a bright gold. In the garden, flowers bloom, and colorful petals attract bees and butterflies, showing the gentle change of seasons. Since I began my career as a fiction writer, I have often switched between writing novels and short stories. My routine is this: after finishing a novel, I want to write short stories; after completing a set of short stories, I feel ready to focus on a novel. I never write short stories while working on a novel, and vice versa. The two types of writing may engage different parts of the brain, and it takes time to switch from one to the other. I started my career with two short novels in 1975, and from 1984 to 1985, I began writing short stories. I knew little about writing short stories then, so it was challenging, but I found the experience memorable. I felt my fictional world expand, and readers seemed to enjoy this different side of me as a writer. One of my early works, 'Breaking Waves', was included in my first short-story collection, Tales from Abroad. This marked my beginning as a short-story writer. One joy of writing short stories is that they don’t take long to finish. Usually, it takes me about a week to shape a short story (though revisions can take longer). It’s not the same total commitment required for the year or two it takes to write a novel. You enter a room, finish your work, and leave. For me, writing a novel can feel endless, and I sometimes wonder if I will make it through. So, writing short stories provides a necessary change of pace. Another nice thing about short stories is that you can create a story from the smallest ideas—an idea, a word, an image, anything. Often, it feels like jazz improvisation, with the story leading me where it wants to go. Plus, with short stories, you don’t have to worry about failing. If an idea doesn’t work out, you can simply accept it and move on. Even great writers like F. Scott Fitzgerald and Raymond Carver didn’t write a masterpiece every time. This comforts me. You can learn from your mistakes and use that knowledge in your next story. When I write novels, I try to learn from both the successes and failures I experience in writing short stories. In this way, short stories serve as a kind of experimental space for me as a novelist. It is hard to experiment the way I like within a novel, so without short stories, writing novels would be even more difficult. My short stories are like soft shadows I have placed in the world, faint traces I have left behind. I remember exactly where I created each one and how I felt at that moment. Short stories are like guideposts to my heart, and it makes me happy as a writer to share these personal feelings with my readers."

Text: 'At its core, science is closely related to philosophy, but it also has practical applications, such as curing diseases. It has improved our lives but also posed threats to our existence. Science seeks to understand everything from tiny atoms to the vast universe, but it often falls short. It influences poets, politicians, philosophers, and even frauds. The beauty of science is often recognized only by those who study it, while its dangers are frequently misunderstood. Its significance has been both exaggerated and underestimated, and the mistakes made by scientists are often overlooked or unfairly highlighted.

The history of science is marked by constant conflict. Established theories are often changed or completely rejected, similar to how new music styles are initially mocked before becoming accepted. The battle between old and new ideas is rarely respectful. Scientists can be driven by jealousy and anger. The history of science is fundamentally about conflict. This book will explore scientific ideas that have transformed not just science, but also many areas of human thought. While science has practical benefits, our focus will be on the ideas themselves, appreciating their beauty and being ready to question them. We must recognize both the creativity and the limitations of the human mind.

Science is inherently changeable. There is always a scientist challenging the ideas of another. Most of the time, these changes do not disrupt society. However, sometimes significant shifts can challenge our established beliefs. For example, in the seventeenth century, science introduced the idea of a mechanical universe, like a giant clock. Three hundred years later, physics began to question basic assumptions, leading us to a complex understanding where our observations can influence the universe, and we struggle to grasp the true meaning of fundamental concepts.

Some people view the instability of scientific theories as a sign that science cannot explain the universe. However, scientific changes usually enhance our ability to understand and predict natural events. The seventeenth-century scientist Isaac Newton could explain much more than the ancient Greek thinker Aristotle, and Albert Einstein, the founder of modern physics, could explain even more than Newton. Science may falter, but it continues to progress. 

It is important to remember that at the end of the nineteenth century, many physicists believed there was little left to discover in physics. Then came breakthroughs like radioactivity, X-rays, the discovery of the electron and the nucleus, and many new particles, along with quantum mechanics and relativity. Biology has also made significant advances. Currently, some claim that a complete theory explaining the universe's origins and workings is on the horizon. 

Science is not just a harmless intellectual activity. Over the last two centuries, we have shifted from merely observing nature to controlling it in small but growing ways. This has sometimes disrupted the natural balance in ways we do not fully understand. It is crucial for non-scientists to engage with scientific advancements, as these will shape the world their children will live in. Science has become a key part of how humanity envisions and shapes its future. The questions raised by science are not just for philosophers; the answers can impact national budgets, the health of future generations, and even the long-term survival of life on Earth.'

Text: 'Since around 2015, after many years of growth, major publishers began to notice that ebook sales had leveled off or even decreased in some cases. This raised new questions about the long-term future of ebooks in the publishing industry. One anonymous publishing executive recently admitted that the excitement around ebooks may have led to poor investments, causing his company to lose faith in “the power of the word on the page.” Despite the clear idea that digital and print books can coexist in the market, the debate about whether ebooks will replace print books continues. Whether people are trying to predict or dismiss this possibility, what matters is that the potential loss of print books continues to spark our imagination and provoke strong discussions. Why is this idea so compelling? Why do we see the relationship between ebooks and print books as a conflict, even when evidence suggests otherwise? The answers to these questions go beyond ebooks and reveal much about our mixed feelings of excitement and fear regarding innovation and change. In my research, I have explored how the idea of one medium “killing” another often follows the introduction of new technologies. Even before digital technologies, critics predicted the end of existing media. For example, after television was invented, many believed radio would disappear. However, radio survived by finding new ways to be used; people began listening in cars, on trains, and in factories. The idea of the disappearing book is not new either. As early as 1894, there were concerns that the phonograph would replace books with what we now call audiobooks. This pattern has repeated itself many times. Movies, radio, television, hyperlinks, and smartphones have all been thought to threaten print books as sources of culture and entertainment. Some believed the end of books would lead to cultural decline, while others, imagining a perfect digital future, exaggerated the benefits of ebooks. It is no coincidence that the idea of the death of the book arises during times of technological change. This narrative reflects our mixed feelings of hope and fear about technological advancements. To understand why these reactions are so common, we must consider that we form emotional connections with different media as they become essential parts of our lives. Many studies have shown how we develop strong attachments to objects like books, televisions, and computers, even naming our cars or expressing frustration at our laptops. Therefore, the arrival of new technology, like e-readers, does not just signal economic and social change; it also forces us to rethink our relationship with something that has become a vital part of our daily lives. As technology evolves, we often find ourselves missing what we once knew but no longer have. This is why entire industries emerge around retro products and older technologies. For instance, the spread of the printing press in 15th-century Europe led people to seek out original manuscripts. The transition from silent to sound movies in the 1920s created nostalgia for the older format. The same occurred with the shift from analog to digital photography and from vinyl records to CDs. Unsurprisingly, e-readers have sparked a renewed appreciation for the physical qualities of “old” books, including their often distinct smell. This should reassure those who worry about the decline of print books. However, the idea of a disappearing medium will continue to be an attractive narrative about both the transformative power of technology and our resistance to change. In fact, one way we cope with change is by using familiar narrative patterns, such as stories of tragedy and endings. Easy to remember and share, the story of the death of the book reflects both our excitement for the future and our fear of losing parts of our familiar world—and ultimately, of ourselves.'

Text: 'For a year and a half, I woke up at 5:30 every weekday morning. I brushed my teeth, made coffee, and wrote about how some of the greatest thinkers of the last four hundred years managed their time to do their best work. I focused on the daily lives of these individuals – when they slept, ate, worked, and worried – to offer a new perspective on their personalities and careers. I wanted to create interesting, small portraits of these artists as people with routines, just like us. The French gastronome Jean Anthelme Brillat-Savarin once said, “Tell me what you eat, and I shall tell you what you are.” I would say, “Tell me what time you eat, and if you take a nap afterward.” In this way, the book is somewhat superficial. It looks at the conditions of creative work, not the final product; it focuses on the process rather than the meaning. However, it is also personal. The novelist John Cheever believed that even a business letter reveals something about the writer – and he was right. My main concerns in this book reflect my own struggles: How can you do meaningful creative work while making a living? Is it better to focus entirely on one project or to work a little each day? When time is limited, do you have to give up things like sleep, income, or a tidy home, or can you learn to do more in less time, to “work smarter, not harder,” as my dad always says? I do not claim to answer these questions in the following pages – some may not have clear answers, or may only be resolved through personal compromises – but I have tried to show how many brilliant and successful people have faced similar challenges. I wanted to illustrate how big creative ideas can be broken down into small daily actions, and how one’s habits can affect their work and vice versa. The book is called Daily Rituals, but I really focused on people’s routines. The word suggests something ordinary and thoughtless; following a routine can feel automatic. However, a good routine can help you use limited resources like time, willpower, and optimism effectively. A strong routine creates a path for your mental energy and helps manage your moods. The psychologist William James believed that putting part of your life on autopilot through good habits allows us to focus on more interesting activities. Ironically, James himself struggled with procrastination and could not stick to a regular schedule. Interestingly, it was a moment of procrastination that inspired this book. One Sunday afternoon, while working at a small architecture magazine, I was supposed to write a story due the next day. Instead of working, I found myself cleaning my workspace, making coffee, and wasting time. I am a “morning person,” able to concentrate well in the early hours but not very productive after lunch. That afternoon, to feel better about my tendency to procrastinate, I started looking online for information about other writers’ schedules. I found many entertaining stories. I thought someone should gather these anecdotes in one place, which led to the Daily Routines blog I started that day, and now this book. The blog was informal; I simply shared descriptions of people’s routines from biographies, magazine articles, and obituaries. For the book, I have created a much larger and better-researched collection while trying to keep the variety of voices that made the original blog enjoyable. I have let my subjects speak for themselves through quotes from letters, diaries, and interviews. In some cases, I summarized their routines from other sources. I should mention that this book would not have been possible without the research of many biographers, journalists, and scholars whose work I used. I have listed all my sources in the Notes section, which I hope will also guide further reading.'

Text: 'Howard became a palaeontologist because of a rise in interest rates when he was six years old. His father, a careful man with a large mortgage, said that their planned holiday to Spain was no longer possible. Instead, they rented a chalet on the English coast, and on a rainy August afternoon, Howard found an ammonite on the beach. He had always wanted to be a palaeontologist, and by the end of university, he knew what kind he wanted to be. He was interested in the very beginnings of life, rather than the more famous periods like the Jurassic and dinosaurs. He studied small creatures found in grey rocks. As he finished his doctoral thesis, he wondered if he would get a job, especially in the kind of institution he wanted. He was confident in his abilities but knew that deserving a job does not always guarantee getting one. When the Assistant Lectureship at Tavistock College in London became available, he applied, though he did not expect much.

On the day of Howard’s interview, the professor who was supposed to lead the panel had a fight with his wife. He left home upset, crashed his car into a gatepost, and ended up in the hospital. The interview went ahead without him, and the professor who replaced him was someone who disliked Howard’s former professor. This man managed to ensure that Howard got the job. Howard was surprised by this unexpected support and felt grateful until a colleague later explained the situation to him. He was only slightly disappointed; what mattered most was that he had the job and could do the work he loved.

Howard often compared his orderly professional life, where he could plan and pursue scientific truth, with the chaos of personal life. Many people can affect your life, and sometimes a stranger can change everything, as Howard discovered when his briefcase, containing notes for a lecture, was stolen at an Underground station. Upset, Howard returned to the college, made a phone call to postpone the lecture, reported the theft, and then went for a coffee. There, he met a colleague who was with a visiting curator from the Natural History Museum in Nairobi. This conversation led Howard to learn about a new collection of fossils that needed to be studied, which would become his biggest challenge and secure his future. Because of the theft, he changed his plans. He decided not to attend a conference in Stockholm or take students on a field trip to Scotland. Instead, he would find a way to visit the museum in Nairobi.'

Text: 'Charles Spence is open to trying many different foods. “We have ice cream made from bee larvae at home,” says the Professor of Experimental Psychology at Oxford University in the UK. Although they may look like maggots, they are said to have a “slightly nutty, floral” taste. One of the challenges Spence and his team are working on is how to make eating insects more acceptable. Through his research on how our senses work together to create our experience of flavor, Spence is quietly influencing what we eat and drink. This includes the products of large food companies (he advises one well-known company and receives funding from another) and the menus of top restaurants. Spence and his colleagues study how we experience food and drink in detail, a field informally called gastro physics. Factors like who we eat with, how food is presented, the color and weight of plates and cutlery, and background noise all affect our taste. Spence’s book, The Perfect Meal, co-written with Betina Piqueras-Fiszman, is full of interesting facts for anyone who enjoys food. For example, did you know that the first person to order in a restaurant usually enjoys their meal the most? And that we eat about 35% more food when dining with one other person, and 75% more with three others? 

Spence’s lab in Oxford is not high-tech. “It’s low-tech, just paper and drawing pins,” he says. There are soundproof booths that look like large safes, where he did much of his PhD work, and old audio-visual equipment. By keeping costs low, he can work creatively with chefs who cannot afford academic research. Much of his work is funded by a large food company. He notes that in the past, research funded by industry was often seen as less serious in universities. However, since the government required universities to show their work has an impact, this type of research has become more accepted. Spence is currently helping well-known brands reduce salt and sugar in their products, which is important for keeping customers healthy. Interestingly, many companies have been making these changes quietly, so customers do not notice the difference. “Research shows that when you inform people about changes, they focus on the taste and often do not like it as much,” he explains. 

Spence first met the famous experimental chef Heston Blumenthal while working on a project for a major food company. “At that time, people thought science and food did not mix, but most food is scientific,” he says. Blumenthal’s collaboration with Spence, who studied how sound affects flavor, led to the creation of the “Sound of the Sea” dish in Blumenthal’s five-star restaurant. Interestingly, Spence points out that members of the early-twentieth-century Italian futurist art movement experimented with sounds and food, but it did not become popular. Now, the food industry is applying Spence’s sensory science to many products. For example, he has found that higher-pitched music makes food taste sweeter, while lower-pitched sounds can make it taste bitter. “It’s surprising how shapes can affect taste, or how a tune can change how you perceive a flavor,” he says. An airline will soon match music with the food served to passengers. Last year, a well-known brand released a smartphone app that played music while your ice cream melted, but they did not match the music to the taste, which is often the case, according to Spence. 

What are dinner parties like at the Spence home? One time, they had rabbit with the fur wrapped around the cutlery. Another time, they used remote-controlled, multi-colored light bulbs. “We’ve had dinner parties with a tone generator, headphones, and ten different drinks to see if they have different pitches.” For Spence, home, sweet shops, food conventions, and international gastronomy conferences are all extensions of his lab.'

Text: 'Our brains are busier than ever. We are bombarded with facts, false information, chatter, and rumors, all pretending to be useful information that we must sort through to find what we need and what we can ignore. At the same time, we are doing more than before. Thirty years ago, travel agents booked our flights and salespeople helped us find what we needed in stores. Now, we do most things ourselves. We are doing the work of many people while trying to manage our lives, families, careers, hobbies, and favorite TV shows, with the help of our smartphones. They have become part of the 21st-century rush to fill every spare moment. However, there is a problem. Although we believe we are multitasking – doing several things at once – this is a strong and dangerous illusion. Earl Miller, a neuroscientist at MIT, says that our brains are ‘not wired to multitask well.’ When people think they are multitasking, they are actually switching quickly from one task to another. Each time they switch, there is a mental cost. So, we are not juggling many tasks like experts; we are more like amateur plate spinners, hurriedly moving from one task to another, ignoring the one that is not in front of us but worried it will fall. Even though we think we are accomplishing a lot, multitasking actually makes us less efficient. It has been shown that multitasking increases the stress hormone cortisol and the fight-or-flight hormone adrenaline, which can overstimulate our brains and lead to confusion. Multitasking creates a craving, rewarding the brain for losing focus and constantly seeking new stimulation. Additionally, the prefrontal cortex, the area of the brain we need to focus, can easily be distracted by new things – like shiny objects that attract infants. The irony is that the very part of the brain we need to stay on task is easily sidetracked. Just having the chance to multitask harms our cognitive performance. Glenn Wilson, a former psychology professor, calls this info-mania. His research found that trying to focus on a task while an unread email is in your inbox can lower your IQ by almost 10 points. Wilson showed that the cognitive losses from multitasking are even greater than those caused by tiredness. Russ Poldrack, a neuroscientist at Stanford, found that learning new information while multitasking sends the information to the wrong part of the brain. For example, if students do their homework while watching TV, the information from their schoolwork goes to the striatum, a part of the brain for storing new skills, instead of facts and ideas. Without the distraction of TV, the information goes to the hippocampus, where it is organized and categorized, making it easier to remember. Moreover, multitasking often involves decision-making: ‘Should I answer this text or ignore it? How should I respond?’ Decision-making is also hard on our brains, and small decisions use the same mental resources as big ones. We can quickly become mentally exhausted, and after making many small decisions, we may end up making poor choices about important matters. In discussions about information overload with business leaders and scientists, email is often mentioned as a problem. It is not a dislike of email itself, but rather the overwhelming amount of communication we receive. When the 10-year-old son of my neuroscience colleague was asked what his father does, he said, ‘He answers emails.’ My colleague admitted that this is quite true. We feel we must reply to our emails, but it seems impossible to do so and accomplish anything else.'

In a zoo in Sweden, a chimpanzee named Santino spent his nights breaking concrete into pieces to throw at visitors during the day. Was he being mean? In caves in the US, female bats help unrelated fruit bat mothers if they cannot find the right position to give birth. Are they being kind? Fifty years ago, these questions would have seemed unimportant. Animals had behaviors, those behaviors led to measurable results, and science recorded those results. The idea that animals have thoughts, feelings, and moral systems was considered overly sentimental. However, this view has started to change. Research on the behavior of bats, chimps, rats, dolphins, and chickens has begun to explore animal emotions, which were once a taboo subject. This shift has influenced popular science books, such as Mark Bekoff’s "Wild Justice" and Victoria Braithwaite’s "Do Fish Feel Pain?". This change has sparked a debate that may never be resolved: do animals have consciousness? This debate leads to another important question: do animals have a moral sense that guides their behavior? 

In a recent experiment with cows that had to open a locked gate to get food, it was clear that those who opened the gate themselves showed more happiness—by jumping and kicking their legs—than those who had the gate opened for them. If this research suggests that cows enjoy solving problems, what does it mean for how we produce and consume beef? While the observations may not be disputed, their interpretation is. Dr. Jonathan Balcombe, author of "Second Nature," argues that the only logical response to this new research is to stop eating meat. He believes humanity is on the brink of a major ethical revolution, similar to the abolition of slavery. Aubrey Manning, a professor at Edinburgh University, suggests we should at least reconsider our views on animal intelligence. He believes that animals likely have a simpler understanding of the mind than humans do. Professor Euan MacPhail thinks we should avoid attributing human emotions to animals. These three perspectives may never agree because the core issue is not just scientific or moral, but philosophical. Since defining consciousness is very difficult, can we ever truly understand, as philosopher Thomas Nagel asks, what it is like to be a bat? 

Balcombe describes an important experiment he conducted that seems to show that starlings, a type of bird, can feel depressed. In a study at Newcastle University, starlings were divided into two groups. One group lived in spacious, comfortable cages, while the other group lived in small, empty cages. Initially, both groups were fed tasty worms from one box and unpleasant worms from another, and they quickly learned to take only from the tasty box. However, when only unpleasant worms were offered, only the starlings in the comfortable cages would eat. Balcombe concluded that being in a bad cage made the starlings pessimistic about life. Balcombe, who has worked with animal rights groups, has a clear bias. He says, “We look back with horror on a time when there was racism. Our views about animals will one day be the same. We cannot support animal rights while eating a cheeseburger.” If he were the only one with this view of animal consciousness, it might be easy to dismiss him as extreme. However, Professor Aubrey Manning shares similar views. Manning has written a textbook called "An Introduction to Animal Behaviour." He states, “What we are seeing is a swing in perspective. At the start of the 20th century, some people believed animals thought just like us, and there was a backlash against that. Now we are moving back in that direction. But this is a very controversial topic, and we should be careful of academics with strong personal opinions.”

Text: 'Critical thinking is a way of engaging with what we read or hear to gain a deeper understanding. Adrian West, a research director at the Edward de Bono Foundation U.K., notes that many believe argument is a way to discover the truth. While information technology helps us store and process large amounts of data, there are growing concerns that it is changing how we tackle complex problems and making it harder to think deeply. West points out that we are often exposed to poor but appealing ideas, trends, and opinions, which can overwhelm our ability to reason. Ironically, having more data does not necessarily lead to better knowledge or decision-making. West highlights that this has not significantly improved the quality of our thinking. According to the National Endowment for the Arts, literary reading has dropped by 10 percentage points, and this decline is speeding up. Patricia Greenfield, a psychology professor, believes that the increased focus on visual media has a cost. She suggests that the decline in reading may be linked to a decrease in critical thinking, as people are more focused on real-time media and multitasking rather than concentrating on one task. However, there is still no clear answer on how technology impacts critical thinking. The presence of technology has complicated the situation, making it hard for academics to rely on previous beliefs. It is tempting to see computers, video games, and the internet as either good or bad, but the truth is they can be both, and different technologies can lead to different outcomes. For instance, a computer game might encourage critical thinking or hinder it. Reading online can improve analytical skills, while endlessly clicking on links may prevent deeper thinking. Greenfield, who studied over 50 research papers on learning and technology, states that technology changes how people think. She observes that reading fosters thinking and imagination in ways that visual media like video games and television do not. Reading develops imagination, reflection, critical thinking, and vocabulary. However, she also found that visual media can enhance some types of information processing. Unfortunately, most visual media are real-time and do not allow for reflection or analysis. As a result, many people, especially younger individuals, may not reach their full potential. Society's view of technology greatly influences how it perceives critical thinking. The conflict is especially clear in the area of video games and cognition. James Paul Gee, an educational psychology professor, argues that video and computer games are often misunderstood. He explains that they are not only a popular form of entertainment but can also be effective learning tools. Evidence suggests that video games can help develop better reasoning skills in children. Games like Sim City and Civilization go beyond simple memorization and teach decision-making and analytical skills in engaging, virtual settings that mimic the real world. These games also allow players to explore ideas and concepts that might otherwise be difficult to access. In the digital age, as reading and math scores decline, it is important to closely examine technology and understand how it influences thinking and analysis.'

When Matthew Crawford is not thinking and writing about how we should live, he works as a motorcycle mechanic. He chose this job after becoming unhappy with office work and his role in social policy institutions. His first book was a thoughtful piece about the advantages of manual trades. His latest book is a philosophical discussion on how to deal with modern life. He was inspired to write it when he noticed advertisements appearing on the credit card machine during a brief moment while he entered his pin number. Crawford realized that these demands on our attention are becoming harder to escape. What we want to focus on at any moment is very personal, but we are often unaware of how outside influences affect our choices. It is increasingly difficult to think or remember conversations we’ve had. To avoid constant interruptions, we tend to isolate ourselves and stop doing simple things like talking to strangers. Crawford notes, “We increasingly encounter the world through representations that are often manipulative: video games, apps on your phone.” These representations reflect our desires perfectly and can take over our lives. 

Crawford is not alone in his concerns. Many people know an office worker who complains about emails all day but spends their free time checking emails. Studies show that our attention can wander if a phone is simply visible on the table – a common experience for those who have felt distracted at dinner by the phone in their pocket. There is no scientific proof yet that our attention spans have changed, but there have been worries about this since the telegraph was invented in 1837. It is clear, however, that we are more aware of other things we could be doing. While it is easy to blame technology for this crisis, Crawford believes that technology has created perfect tools for our self-obsession. Living in a world of constant choices makes it hard to control ourselves, which affects our social interactions. We often prefer to send a text message to a friend instead of risking a face-to-face conversation. By only interacting with representations of people rather than real people, Crawford argues, we may lose something essential in our society.

Screens are only part of the issue. Crawford uses his gym as an example. There used to be one music player in the middle of the room for everyone to share. People had different music tastes, which could lead to tension. Now, people usually listen to their own music through earbuds. “The gym used to be a social place, but it has lost that character. Real connections with others often happen through conflict – discussing different tastes and finding common ground,” he says. 

Crawford suggests a two-part solution. First, we need to regulate noise and distractions in public spaces. More importantly, he believes we should engage in skilled practices to connect with the world in a more fulfilling way. He mentions cooks, ice-hockey players, and motorcycle racers as examples of people whose jobs require them to deal with real materials. No representation can match the feeling of a hockey puck on ice or gravel under your tires at high speed. Each of these roles requires good judgment and the ability to manage interactions with others in the same space. “When you engage with the world this way, manufactured experiences are revealed as poor substitutes for real involvement,” he says. “They lose some of their power.” This does not mean everyone should become a chef; rather, it is important to find ways to use your judgment. There are many benefits beyond job satisfaction. Constantly fighting distractions can be tiring and makes it harder to focus on what is important. In contrast, practicing attention on one thing makes it easier to pay attention to others.

Text: 

"What do you do for a living?" This is a common question in small talk, and we often define ourselves by our jobs. However, if you are a philosopher, like me, it can be more complicated. Saying you are a philosopher can sound pretentious. It is acceptable to say you study or teach philosophy, but claiming to be a philosopher may suggest you believe you have special knowledge or insight. This idea is misleading; philosophers are just like everyone else. 

So why do people have this stereotype of philosophers? One reason is that philosophers often judge the actions of others and value intellectual life. The Greek philosopher Aristotle (384 – 322 BCE) believed that a life of contemplation, or philosophical living, was the best kind of life. While few modern philosophers agree with this, philosophy is still associated with deep thinking. Another Greek philosopher, Socrates, said that "the unexamined life is not worth living," meaning that simply accepting societal norms can lead to an unsatisfying life. Our ability to reflect on the world helps us control our lives and make our own choices.

However, living an examined life does not require extensive reading of philosophical texts or a life focused solely on intellectual thought. It means paying closer attention to our everyday experiences to ensure they are meaningful. You do not need to be a wise person living apart from society to evaluate life fairly. In fact, examining life can be very practical and should involve sharing knowledge, as it is essential for a good life.

Another reason for the misunderstanding about philosophers is that academic philosophy has become more disconnected from real-life experiences, especially for those without formal training. This is not entirely the philosophers' fault; university funding and evaluations are linked to expensive academic journals. As a result, philosophers often have little chance to share their ideas with anyone outside their small group of experts. For many, philosophy can seem distant from reality. While some philosophers have tried to change this view, many have accepted it. The academic environment has created a sense of isolation, and as philosophy has become more focused on specific debates, it has become harder for those outside the field to understand.

I sometimes call myself an "ethicist" because most of my work is in ethics, which is the area of philosophy that examines human actions. Recently, I have felt that this title does not fully capture my work, as ethics is often linked to formal rules and values. There is a new trend in philosophy where ethics is seen as applied ethics, which looks at the fairness of specific social practices. The role of the ethicist today is to decide if certain actions are "ethical" or acceptable. These are important questions that I often explore.

However, philosophy is more than just this. A typical discussion might start by asking if illegally downloading films is unethical (it is) and then move on to questions about responsibility, our views on art, and the effects of consumerism. In this way, philosophy can help people examine the practices and behaviors that shape their lives. Sometimes this examination confirms what we already know; other times, it reveals that our beliefs are difficult to justify. Either way, by exploring these ideas, we contribute to the benefit of everyone.

Text: 'People who love food, like foodies and chefs, might think that thinking deeply about what and how we eat can make eating more enjoyable. However, throughout history, discussions about food in philosophy have often been less important than other philosophical topics. When philosophers have discussed eating, it has usually been a way to talk about something else, like gaining knowledge. Sometimes, there are philosophical discussions that seem to be about food, but a closer look shows they are really about different, but related, ideas. 

One interesting example is the ancient Greek philosopher Epicurus, who believed in seeking pleasure and avoiding pain in many areas of life. Despite this, his name has become closely linked to a love for eating and drinking. We see his name used in restaurants, food shops, and recipe websites, likely because these businesses hope to attract customers by associating with a famous philosopher. 

Food is also a social and cultural experience. The food we eat comes from historical backgrounds and is shared with our communities. These communities provide us with people to eat with and the systems that help grow and distribute food. We interact with food more often and in more important ways than with any other product, making it a clear topic for philosophical discussion. 

Once food is ready, critics begin to talk and write about it. But why do these critics have such a special status? One philosopher pointed out that tasting food is not a unique skill; rather, good food critics are simply better at describing flavors. This area has not been studied much in philosophy, as most research on perception has focused on sight, which should change. 

Another important aspect of food is its beauty. We often describe paintings or music as beautiful, but we rarely talk about the taste of food in the same way. Some philosophers argue that, with the growth of modern cooking, food deserves to be discussed in terms of beauty, just like art or poetry. However, food is consumed and disappears when we enjoy it, unlike art, which remains. Aesthetic objects need to last over time, so it is incorrect to think of food as having true aesthetic value. 

There are also many ethical questions related to food. We can ask what we should eat: organic, free-range, locally grown, vegetarian, or non-genetically modified foods? The answers often reflect our ethical beliefs, and philosophers will always question why we choose what we do; discussing these issues is important in relation to food. 

Cooking at home and in restaurants can be quite different. Home cooks have a special responsibility to their guests because of their personal relationships. In a home kitchen, everyone is included as we gather to share food and companionship. In contrast, professional cooks have responsibilities to their employers and the food itself. Their kitchens are not open to everyone, but only to those who are qualified, and their relationships are more like colleagues than friends. 

A recent essay called ‘Diplomacy of the Dish’ looks at how food and dining can help connect different cultures. This happens in two ways: first, we can learn to appreciate others by enjoying their food; second, we build personal connections with people from other cultures by sharing meals, a practice that has a long history in international relations. The essay is filled with great examples and entertaining stories, making this part of food philosophy engaging for everyone.'

Rob Daviau, from the United States, creates ‘legacy’ board games. He felt that the traditional board games he enjoyed as a child were no longer fun or challenging, so he began to think about how board games could change. Could they have a story? Could choices made in one game affect future games? He modified a classic game called Risk to create a new version called Risk Legacy. For the first time, decisions made during the game had lasting effects. Players might have to tear up cards, mark the board, or open packets with new rules at important moments. The games are played over a set number of sessions, and long-standing rivalries become part of the game. Daviau explained: ‘You could point to the board and say: “Right here! You did this!”’ 

He was later invited to work on a legacy version of Pandemic, a very popular cooperative board game where players try to cure diseases that threaten humanity. His next project was a game called SeaFall. While Pandemic Legacy received much praise, SeaFall was seen as a true test of the legacy format because it was the first game that did not follow an earlier version. Set in the age of sailing (16th to mid-19th century), players become sailors exploring a new world. Designers of legacy board games must think about all possible player choices to keep the story coherent. To do this, they use testers to see how the games will play out. Jaime Barriga was a play-tester for SeaFall. He said, ‘It takes a huge amount of time. The first few games might go well, but then after a few more, it can start to fall apart, and you have to go back and fix everything.’

Legacy board games were not expected to become very popular. When developing the idea, Daviau thought it would appeal to a small group of people. He said, ‘I thought it was really different and pretty good, but it’s unusual and breaks many rules. I expected it to be successful with just a few people. I thought I would be known as the guy who did this strange project.’ However, many players, like Russell Chapman, loved the idea. He believes it is one of the biggest advancements in game design in recent years. ‘It brings a new level of commitment, intensity, and excitement,’ he said. ‘There’s nothing more thrilling for a board gamer than to learn a new game or a new way to play, and you get that constantly with legacy games.’

Another fan, Ben Hogg, said that the excitement of an unfolding adventure outweighed any worries about the game lasting. ‘At first, I was worried about making changes and ruining my board,’ he said. ‘But that concern was eased by Pandemic Legacy. Most people don’t go to the cinema to watch the same movie twice, do they? You’re buying into an experience. It adds a storytelling aspect similar to video games.’ The legacy format is influenced not only by video games but also by the demand for episodic entertainment from popular TV shows. While in college, Daviau thought he would become a television writer, but he moved into advertising and then game design. Still, he loved telling stories. Pandemic creator Matt Leacock compares the legacy design process to writing a novel. ‘You need to know how you want it to end and have a good idea of where to start,’ he said. ‘But it’s not enough to just have a general outline.’

While Daviau feels a sense of ownership over the idea, he is curious to see how others will develop it. However, he also tries to downplay its importance. He thinks gamers will soon be asking, ‘What’s next?’ Colby Dauch, the studio manager for the publisher of SeaFall, is less certain. For him, the legacy format has been a revelation. ‘It’s an idea that changes how you think about what a board game can be.’

Text: 'Recently, an octopus named Inky escaped from his tank at New Zealand’s National Aquarium. He crawled across the floor and squeezed into a narrow drain that led to the Pacific Ocean. This story, which sounds like a children’s movie, became popular online. Part of the enjoyment comes from seeing animals as similar to us. Octopuses are especially interesting because they are very intelligent and have bodies that are very different from ours. They can open jars, recognize faces, use coconut shells for protection, and even play in complex ways. 

Some people think that seeing animals as similar to humans is unscientific. However, Dr. Frans de Waal, who studies primates like gorillas and chimpanzees, believes that it is actually a mistake to ignore the human-like qualities of animals. He calls this mistake "anthropodenial." After studying many years of research on animal intelligence, he shows that animals, except for their lack of fully developed language, display many behaviors once thought to be unique to humans. These include the ability to think about the past and future, show empathy, and understand the intentions of others. In other words, animals are much smarter than we often believe.

De Waal thinks that anthropodenial is a recent idea. In medieval and early modern Europe, people believed that animals were intelligent enough to be put on trial for crimes. Even in the nineteenth century, many scientists looked for similarities between human and animal intelligence. Charles Darwin, who changed our understanding of evolution, wrote that the difference between humans and higher animals is one of degree, not kind.

In the twentieth century, behaviorism became popular, focusing on training animals through rewards and punishments. During this time, many people viewed animals as simple machines or robots with instincts. Those who believed animals had inner lives were often seen as unrealistic. This change in thinking happened at the same time that humans were destroying animal habitats, polluting the environment, and treating livestock poorly.

Fortunately, de Waal believes we are starting to recognize animal intelligence again. He notes that there has been a lot of new information about animal cognition shared online in recent years. He argues that the best tests of animal intelligence consider the unique traits of each species. For example, squirrels may not do well on human memory tests, but they can remember where they hid their nuts. 

In her book, The Soul of an Octopus, naturalist Sy Montgomery suggests that if an octopus were to test human intelligence, it might focus on how many color patterns we can create on our skin. If we failed, the octopus might think we are not very smart. 

De Waal is cautious about Inky’s escape. He believes that while octopuses have escaped before, it is unlikely that Inky knew how to reach the drain leading to the ocean. However, he understands how powerful stories like Inky’s can help people appreciate animal intelligence. 

He once conducted an experiment to see if capuchin monkeys could feel envy. When some monkeys received cucumbers (a food they liked) and others received grapes (which they liked even more), the monkeys with cucumbers became upset when they saw their friends getting grapes. The study was published in a well-known scientific journal, but what really made people believe the results was a short video of the experiment released ten years later. This shows how our understanding of animal minds can be quite unique.'

Text: 'Robotics, once a topic in science fiction, is now set to cause major changes in technology, similar to the impact of industrialisation. Robots have been used in car manufacturing and other industries for many years, but experts believe we are about to see a significant increase in their use across various fields. Many people see robotic automation as a disruptive force. Interestingly, while about two-thirds of people think robots will take over most jobs done by humans in the next 50 years, around 80% believe their own jobs will still exist in the same way during that time. This shows a common belief that our jobs are safe, but they are not: every industry will be affected by robotic automation soon. 

For instance, the Australian company Fastbrick Robotics has created a robot called Hadrian X, which can lay 1,000 bricks in one hour, a task that would take two human workers a whole day or more. Two years ago, the San Francisco startup Simbe Robotics introduced Tally, a robot that moves through supermarket aisles to check that products are well-stocked, placed correctly, and priced right, rather than just cleaning the aisles. 

Supporters of robotic automation often point out that robots currently cannot maintain or program themselves, which could lead to new, skilled jobs for technicians and programmers. However, critics warn that we should not ignore the importance of human skills in the workplace. They believe society is unprepared for the changes that will come from reducing human interaction. Dr. Jing Bing Zhang, a leading expert on robotics in business, understands this issue well. As a research director at IDC, he studies how robotics is changing the workforce. 

A recent report by Zhang and his team predicts that in two years, nearly one-third of robots will be smarter and more efficient, able to work with other robots and alongside humans safely. In three years, 30% or more of top companies will have a chief robotics officer, and many governments will create laws about robots. In five years, salaries in the robotics field will rise by at least 60%, but over one-third of jobs in this area will remain unfilled due to a lack of skilled workers. Zhang stated, ‘Automation and robotics will impact lower-skilled workers, which is unfortunate. The best way for them to adapt is not to rely on the government to protect their jobs, but to find ways to retrain themselves. No one can expect to do the same job for life anymore.’

At the same time, advancements in motion control, sensors, and artificial intelligence will lead to new types of robots for consumers, including upright, walking robots that live in our homes and interact with us in advanced ways—robots that were once only imagined in science fiction. Zhang believes this presents a unique opportunity for companies ready to embrace this change, but it also brings challenges, such as the need for new regulations to ensure safety and privacy. With millions of jobs at risk and a global employment crisis approaching, it is essential to focus on education to prepare for the future workforce that will include robots. Developed countries need more graduates in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) to stay competitive.'

Text: George Mallory, a mountaineer, is famously quoted as saying he wanted to climb Mount Everest "because it’s there." This response reflects a common question people have: why do climbers take on such dangerous challenges? Mallory's answer might inspire some to pursue their dreams and encourages certain individuals to confront the unknown. However, it also suggests that the main reason for climbing could simply be for adventure and enjoyment.

In 1967, Bolivian writer Tejada-Flores wrote an important essay called "Games that Climbers Play." He identified seven different climbing activities, or "games," ranging from bouldering to climbing high peaks, each with its own rules. He argued that the approach to any climb, such as the amount of equipment used, should depend on the rules of that specific game. Over the years, this perspective has become popular in climbing discussions in the West, appearing in climbing magazines and casual conversations.

Many climbers love the sense of freedom that climbing brings. Yet, climbing can also feel restrictive. For instance, being stuck in a tent during a storm is not what most people think of as freedom. This creates a paradox in climbing. However, some argue that the limited choices in climbing can simplify life, which can also feel freeing.

When asked "Why climb?", US rock climber Joe Fitschen suggests a different question: "Why do people climb?" He believes that climbing is part of our nature; we are wired to take on challenges and test our limits, even with the risks involved. Therefore, the joy of climbing may be more about our biology than logical reasoning.

US academic Brian Treanor also contributed to this discussion, suggesting that climbing can help develop important qualities like courage, humility, and respect for nature. While he acknowledges that not all climbers show these traits, he believes they are especially important in today's risk-averse society. Climbing, then, can have practical benefits, helping people develop the qualities needed to thrive in everyday life.

Another interesting viewpoint comes from expert climbers Ebert and Robinson, who stirred some debate by claiming that climbs done independently are more challenging and deserve more recognition than those completed with large teams or artificial aids, like bottled oxygen. This claim raised concerns that it might encourage climbers to take unnecessary risks.

Exploring climbing outside the Western perspective reveals that climbers often experience being "in the moment" or "going with the flow." The physical effort of climbing, the meditative state while climbing, and the intuitive problem-solving involved are all key aspects of the activity. Some argue that climbing techniques are similar to those in Zen philosophy, which aims to achieve a state of peace. This idea adds another layer to the question of why people are drawn to climbing.

Text: 'For over sixty years, pianist Alfred Brendel held a prominent place in classical music. He was an intellectual and sometimes serious person who explored and recorded important European piano works. He wrote and performed a lot, but taught very few students. Those who knew him well saw a playful side to him, but this was rarely shown in his concerts. His life was a constant cycle of study, travel, and performance. 

About four or five years ago, a young boy named Kit Armstrong came backstage at one of Brendel’s concerts and asked for lessons. At first, Brendel did not take this request seriously. He had very few students and did not see a reason to start teaching now. He quoted another famous pianist: ‘You don’t hire a mountain guide to teach a child how to walk.’ However, something about the 14-year-old boy caught his attention. Brendel listened to him play and said, ‘He played incredibly well and from memory. Then he gave me a CD of a recital he had performed, and it was so beautiful that I thought, “I must make time for him.” It was a performance that connected every note. It’s rare to find a musician with this kind of understanding and subtlety.’

As Brendel steps back from the public eye, Kit is starting to make his mark, though Brendel is cautious about the young man burning out too soon. Now 19, Kit is always busy outside of lessons—learning new languages, studying math, writing computer code, or playing tennis, all while his mother keeps a close watch. He also composes music. Brendel says, ‘This is very important. Learning to read music well is helped by trying to write your own. I noticed that Kit has an incredible memory and is an excellent sight reader. More importantly, he listens to his own playing, is sensitive to sound, and understands me when I explain things. When I tell him something to do in a piece, he applies it throughout the entire piece.’

Brendel pauses and looks serious. ‘I don’t want to raise expectations. I get very upset when newspapers do this. One article called him the future great pianist of the 21st century, which is very unhelpful. It can be damaging. Like many talented young musicians, he can play some pieces wonderfully, while others need more time and practice. It would be harmful if a critic expected perfection.’

Now at 80 years old, it is heartwarming to see Brendel’s gentler side in his retirement. He explains, ‘When I was young, I didn’t want to be famous in five years, but I hoped to achieve certain things by the age of 50. When I turned 50, I felt I had accomplished most of those goals, but I still wanted to do more, so I continued. Although I don’t have the physical strength now, my mind is always active with many pieces I’ve never played. I don’t perform anymore, but I enjoy this new phase of my career.’

Text: "When I was a child, I thought gardens were beautiful places. My grandfather’s garden was by a river and sloped gently down to the water. Although I couldn’t reach the river, I could hear the water and the birds in the trees. I believed all gardens were like this – peaceful and quiet. My grandfather’s garden was simple. He didn’t have a fancy greenhouse like some neighbors, who used old window frames and patched them with plastic where the glass was broken. 

At home, my father was often quiet and reserved, but he had a sense of humor. He liked to say phrases like, ‘It’s immaterial to me,’ instead of just saying, ‘I don’t mind.’ Deep down, he might have felt disappointed about his life. He left school without qualifications and became a plumber, which he didn’t love. He wasn’t very ambitious, although he and my mother once thought about moving to Canada, but it never happened. 

He was skilled at home repairs, able to build bookshelves or cupboards impressively. My parents only moved house once during their marriage, but my mother was adventurous with furniture. Just when you got used to one chair, another would appear. The biggest change was when a piano arrived. I wanted to like it, but it intimidated me. I only liked the two brass candlesticks on it, but my mother said they were too fancy and they disappeared while I was at school. I was never allowed to play the piano; my sister took lessons instead. When I later asked my mother why I wasn’t given a chance, she simply said, ‘You’d never have practiced.’

Of the three places I could choose to explore – moors, woods, or the river – I always chose the river. I could imagine another world there. With a fishing net over my shoulder, I would walk along the riverbank in old sandals, looking for a good spot to take them off and leave them with my picnic. I would then carefully look for fish in the water to catch and take home. After failing to keep them alive in the backyard, I returned them to the river.

I wanted to leave school as soon as possible, but that seemed unlikely until one day my father said, ‘There’s a job for an apprentice gardener in the Parks Department. I thought you might be interested.’ In that moment, he went against his usual judgment. He might have preferred if I became a carpenter, but I like to think that deep down, he hoped things would turn out well if I worked hard. Maybe I’m fooling myself, but I believe that even though he didn’t like gardening, he had seen my enthusiasm for it and recognized my passion for plants and flowers."

Lawrence MacEwen crouches down on his Scottish island, the Isle of Muck. I do the same. A strong wind from the Atlantic threatens to blow us off the steep cliff at our feet and into the bay 120 meters below, dropping us into the ocean. Then MacEwen’s sheepdog, Tie, approaches, and his blond, bearded owner gently strokes him. Despite the howling wind, MacEwen feels completely at home on his island. He shows me around his neighborhood. Pointing to the north, he shouts, “That island is Eigg. The one to the west is the Isle of Rum. It gets twice as much rain as we do.” I see dark clouds pouring rain on Rum’s tall mountains. “Just beyond Rum is the island of Soay.” 

“I have sheep to move,” MacEwen suddenly says as rain approaches. We start walking down the slopes. As we go, he shares details about the island: Volcanic Muck is three kilometers long and one and a half kilometers wide; its geese eat a lot of grass; and the MacEwen family has lived here for 3,000 years. Herding the sheep interrupts our conversation. Tie, the sheepdog, is trying to circle a flock of sheep but is not doing it well. “Away to me, Tie. Away to me,” means the dog should go to the right. Instead, he runs straight through the flock, causing confusion. “Tie,” MacEwen says with disappointment. “That will never do.” The dog looks ashamed.

The Isle of Muck is mostly run by the MacEwen family. Lawrence manages the farm with his wife, Jenny; their son Colin, who is newly married, takes care of the island cottages; and their daughter Mary runs the island hotel, Port Mor, with her husband, Toby. Mary and Toby enjoy that their two boys can explore the island freely and sail small boats on summer days. “They go out the door and come back only when they’re hungry.” However, island life has its challenges. For example, electricity is only available part of the time. On my first evening, I wait nervously for the lights to come on. The next morning, I find Mary preparing breakfast by flashlight. But I manage, even without mobile phone service. “There is mobile reception on the hill,” Mary tells me. “Most people last a couple of days, then just put their phone away.” So I do the same.

Everything on Muck feels wonderfully surprising. The boat today brings some groceries and three musicians, who arrive with their instruments. Their concert in the island’s tearoom is a great success, with the islanders tapping their feet to the music. That night, sitting by a warm fire while it rains outside, Lawrence MacEwen tells me how he met his wife, Jenny. “Her father saw a small farm on the isle of Soay advertised in the newspaper and bought it without even visiting. He had never been to Scotland. Jenny was sent to manage it.” Did Jenny know anything about running a farm? “She had good typing skills.”

I go to bed listening to the rain and wake up to more rain. But I eat well, as almost all my food comes from the tiny island. Mary sends me to fisherman Sandy Mathers for fresh fish. I carry it back through the village and deliver it to Mary at the kitchen door. By 7 pm, our fish is on the table, incredibly delicious. Also uncertain is my ferry ride the next morning to my next island. Over the past two months, many scheduled ferries had been canceled due to rough seas. If my ferry didn’t come, I would be stuck on Muck for two more days, which, secretly, I longed for.

Text: 'The game design industry was once mainly made up of computer scientists and self-taught individuals, and it did not offer many ways to enter. Often seen as just a hobby for young people, the video games industry is now taken seriously. This may surprise some, but industry experts are not surprised. However, entering this field is not easy. Video game adaptations of new movies require many team members and months of hard work and skill. Like many industries, it can be difficult to break into, but it is growing. Jim Donelly, a spokesperson for an online games magazine, says: “It is very hard to make progress in large companies or to influence major mainstream games. But the industry needs game designers now more than ever. Not just top-level directors who manage entire games, but also those who design systems and individual elements.” 

So, how can you enter this competitive field? Many companies prefer candidates with a degree in computer science, but Jim disagrees. “The only way is to make games. The tools are available. You won’t get a job if you haven’t created something, and you won’t succeed independently if you are not producing work. Game design is more than a job; it is a way of life. Like any creative work, it must be practiced to be real.” Another expert, John Field, offers different advice. “While ‘just doing it’ is important, it is more complex than that. Many people want to work in games, but few meet the industry’s requirements; even fewer have the creativity, technical skills, vision, and entrepreneurial spirit needed to contribute to this evolving field.” 

Can you succeed on your own? “Maybe, but it is quite difficult,” says John. “A good postgraduate course in games can help, providing support and guidance for a year or two. Most game designers start as programmers or artists and work their way up. They are interested in all forms of entertainment and have a strong passion for the arts and contemporary culture. They may have spent some time working after graduation but have realized that games are their true passion. They are not just fans; they are excited about the future of games and understand the growing variety of the medium. Finally, networking is important. This is often overlooked, but to advance in games, as in many fields, you need to make connections.” 

The stereotype of a young boy playing video games has changed to a more accurate view of a mature medium that captures our attention. Families often engage with interactive consoles. Smartphones offer many new games through apps and social media. John believes there is much room for growth. “Games have become popular among larger audiences. They are also a great way to learn, and I see this already significant area as full of new possibilities and opportunities.”'

Text: "Since I was a child, I have always wanted to play football. My dad encouraged me to play, but he never forced me, and I appreciate that. I had a friend whose dad was very demanding. He often said, ‘You can’t do this, you can’t do that.’ My friend could have been a good player, but he lost interest in football and has not played since. I’m glad that didn’t happen to me, but I know it could have been different. When I score an amazing goal from far away, people often say it’s just luck, but it’s not. I have practiced taking long shots since I was young. You can only score great goals by practicing. The best players in the world, who have natural talent, still need years of practice to succeed. Sometimes young players collide on the field, but I learned proper technique. When I teach kids, I focus on helping them enjoy learning skills. At school, I played many sports, from rounders and baseball to athletics and basketball. I know now that a good education is important, but football was my main focus back then. The teachers were doing a good job, but I didn’t realize it at the time. I want my son to have a different experience. We are already trying to read him books, even though he is too young to sit still for long. I hope that his habit of kicking the books around doesn’t mean he will be like me. At the start of my professional football career, the manager made sacrifices so that younger players could join the first team, but he never made a big deal about it. He didn’t gather us and say, ‘This is your chance to prove yourselves,’ but we all understood that we had to. I scored in the first game of the season, but we lost, and a well-known TV presenter said, ‘You can’t win anything with kids.’ This made us realize how much we needed to improve. We had some doubts, but we believed in ourselves as a team despite his words. I depend a lot on my close friends and family. However, having money can sometimes create issues. For instance, people often ask me, ‘Why do you let your mother keep working?’ I have helped my parents financially. I paid off their house loan and bought them a car last Christmas. My family are strong people, and I think they would be upset if they felt they should rely on me. My mum doesn’t earn much as a hairdresser, but she loves her job. On the other hand, I enjoy using my money to help those around me. I have a lot of money, though not as much as people think, but it doesn’t solve all my problems. After I stop playing, I plan to take a year off or even longer to do things I haven’t been able to do. I want to go skiing the day after I retire. I can’t do that now because if I were to break a leg while skiing and couldn’t play football again, I wouldn’t be insured."

Text: 'Sam Carter was the reason we lived at Reef Point. He was my father’s agent in Los Angeles. Out of desperation, he offered to find us a cheap place to live because my father couldn’t write anything while we were there, and Sam was at risk of losing clients and money. During the summer, the beach was empty because the sun was often hidden by sea fogs. Reef Point was rarely visited by day-trippers. The road was not inviting, and the nice resort of La Carmella was just nearby, so people with sense and some money chose to stay there. Only those who were broke or really loved surfing would take the last mile to Reef Point. But now, with the hot weather, the place was full of people and activities. My father was busy every day trying to write a script by a deadline, and he was in a bad mood. Most days, I went out to the beach with a book and my dog, Rusty. When we first moved to Reef Point, we didn’t have a dog, but Rusty decided to join us. I tried to chase him away, but he kept coming back. One morning, I felt sorry for him and gave him some cool water. My father threw a boot at him, but it was just a weak attempt to scare him off. Rusty knew this and came closer. I asked my father, ‘Who does he belong to? He thinks he belongs to us.’ My father replied, ‘You’re wrong, Jane. He thinks we belong to him.’ Rusty loved the beach and often dug things up to bring to me. Sometimes, he found things that didn’t belong to him, like a new sneaker or a bright beach towel, which I had to return to their owners. He liked to swim too and always wanted to come with me, even though I could swim much faster. You’d think he would get tired, but he never did. That day, we had been swimming. My father had finished his script and drove to Los Angeles to deliver it, so Rusty and I spent the afternoon together in the sea. As the sun began to set, it got cooler, and we watched the surfers. They had been surfing all day and didn’t seem to get tired. They would choose a wave and balance perfectly as they rode it to the shore. One surfer caught my attention. She was so graceful that the others looked clumsy next to her. But then she decided to finish for the day and rode in on a final wave. ‘Hi,’ she said, ‘why didn’t you join us?’ ‘I don’t have a surfboard.’ ‘You could get one.’ ‘I have no money.’ ‘You’re British, right? Are you visiting?’ ‘No, I live here.’ ‘Is your father American?’ ‘No. He came here to write a film script based on a novel he wrote.’ ‘Really? Have I heard of him? What’s his name?’ ‘Rufus Marsh.’ ‘You mean, Tall as the Morning?’ I nodded. ‘I read that book completely.’ She looked at me with new interest, and I realized that this was how it usually was. People were friendly but only showed interest when I mentioned Tall as the Morning.'

Text: "‘What have I done?’ Violet Hetherington wondered. She was in a long line at the dock in Southampton, waiting to board the Queen Caroline. The line was spilling out of the area marked ‘Departures’. Her friend Annie had told her, ‘It’s best to arrive late at the docks. If you come too early, you’ll just be waiting around.’ Annie, who was married to a diplomat and loved giving advice, was an experienced traveler. But this time, her advice was wrong. After a while, an announcement came over the loudspeakers: there was a ‘breakdown in the computer system.’ This news made the atmosphere among the waiting passengers tense. Some tried to be patient, while others attempted to stay cheerful, but most people became frustrated.
