They had paid a lot of money for this trip, and many felt it was their last chance for a bit of luxury. The fact that they could not board the ship smoothly did not bode well. Violet felt like leaving. She reached into her bag for her phone and realized it was missing. This was more annoying than the long wait. It made her feel that going on a cruise was a mistake. Now, she had the problem of the missing phone. She couldn’t call the taxi company to see if she had left it there because all her contacts were stored in her phone. This was the very mistake her older son Harry always warned her about. Behind her in the line was a friendly-looking couple. ‘I’m sorry, but I think I left my mobile phone behind. Could I borrow yours to make a quick call?’ Violet used the couple’s phone to call Harry and left a message asking him to ask their neighbor, Kristina, to check if the phone was left behind. If it wasn’t in her apartment, she would be in trouble since she had no other way to find the numbers she needed in New York. Part of her thought, Thank goodness. But she didn’t tell Harry this. Harry believed that, although he was not much older than his mother, he was much more experienced. Daniel, her younger son, was more understanding of her mistakes, but that was because he made them too. Dan might forget to pass the message to Kristina. Eventually, the line started to move, and Violet was directed to a window where she handed over her travel documents and got ready to board. Her heart sank further when she entered the ship’s foyer, which looked like a not-so-grand hotel trying too hard. There were shiny fake wood panels, fancy chandeliers, polished brass, and carpets that looked like those in airports. Violet followed the signs to the ‘Elevators’, which were covered in mirrors and packed with tired passengers who might have preferred not to see their reflections. She was squeezed against the side of the lift as it moved up, stopping at each floor to let people out. Finally, on the twelfth floor, she stepped out into freedom. Thankfully, her room had the balcony she had requested. She had been worried about what to say if it didn’t. Ignoring Annie’s advice to wait for a last-minute deal, she had decided to spend as much as she could to ensure she had a good view of the sea."

Text: 'When John Maloof bought a box of old photo negatives at an estate auction, he had no idea he was about to uncover the mystery of Vivian Maier. Maloof was searching for images for a book about the Portage Park neighborhood in Chicago, but instead, he found 30,000 images taken by Maier, a street photographer known for her remarkable ability to capture striking images. Since then, Maloof has built a collection of Maier’s life and work. In his home attic, he keeps her cameras, 2,000 rolls of film, 3,000 prints, and 100,000 negatives, along with many 8mm movies and audiotapes. One morning, Maloof looked around at everything he had collected. He realized he was on the brink of something special, all by chance. ‘When I bought this, I had no idea what it was,’ Maloof said. ‘I come from a family of flea market sellers and could have easily sold it all to someone else.’ For a while now, Maloof and his friend Anthony Rydzon have been piecing together details of Maier’s life. They reached out to local families who had employed her as a nanny and spoke with staff from the shop where she developed her film. Maier was born in 1926 in New York and spent much of her childhood in France. In 1951, she returned to New York and moved to Chicago in 1956 to work as a nanny. Maier, who was known to be a private person with a unique personality, always carried a camera. She wore oversized coats, wide-brimmed hats, and sturdy shoes. ‘On her day off, the camera was always around her neck, and we wouldn’t see her again until late at night,’ said Maren Baylaender, whose husband employed Maier to care for his daughter. ‘I remember her as a private person but one who had strong opinions about movies and politics.’ Maier was knowledgeable about theater and films. Although she was not very social, she would walk the streets with her camera and talk to people, some of whom she interviewed on audiotape. She seemed to be quite dedicated to her ‘second job’ of documenting the world around her. ‘She was a true artist who followed her dreams,’ said Rydzon. ‘She didn’t let anything stop her.’ Maier’s work is a pure form of art; she did not create it for commercial purposes. Her images often focus on women, children, the elderly, the poor, and abstract subjects. ‘What is fascinating about Vivian is the number of interesting pictures she took,’ said photography expert Larry Silverman. He sees influences from other photographers in her work and wonders if she developed her own style independently. ‘Was Vivian sophisticated enough to do this on her own, or did she borrow ideas from those before her?’ Maloof often wonders if he will ever sort through all the negatives, which he has stored in three tall, fireproof file cabinets. Interestingly, he had no real interest in photography until he discovered Maier’s work. Inspired by her architectural photos, Maloof began to take his own pictures. ‘As I improved as a photographer and revisited her work, I realized that the cityscapes were not what mattered to her. It’s the people, the street scenes, the overall composition,’ he said. ‘There was so much more to her work than I thought, and I realized I was holding something more significant than I ever imagined. Now our goal is to share her name and ensure Vivian Maier is recognized in history.'

When a novel is called ambitious, it often suggests that it has not fully succeeded. However, this is not the case with Eleanor Catton’s book, The Luminaries. I interviewed her in the UK when her book was very successful, and she was at the center of a lot of attention. Despite being in her twenties, she appeared calm. She had just arrived from Germany and was flying back to New Zealand the next day. She shared a story about being stopped at passport control and asked to prove she was a writer. She pressed her novel against the glass, and the official asked, “What’s it about?” This is not an easy question for an author. 

The Luminaries takes place in New Zealand during the 1860s, where a series of crimes have occurred, leading a council of 12 men to come together to solve them. The plot becomes very complex. Catton intended to write a murder mystery, not a historical novel, but she found that the past allowed for more complications and misunderstandings for her characters. At over 800 pages, the book is “big by necessity” because she wanted to give each of the 20 main characters a fair chance to shine.

When I asked her how it feels to be so successful at a young age, she responded thoughtfully. “It’s nice coming from a small country because everyone feels like the success is partly theirs. There’s a family-like feeling at home; I received a lot of support from other people’s grandmas.” She also mentioned that it annoys her when people assume her book is not a philosophical work.

Catton explained that she wanted to write the book in the shape of a spiral, with each part being half the length of the one before it. This structure makes the story speed up as it progresses. I asked if it matters whether readers notice these patterns. She said she aimed to create a book with structural patterns that were not essential, but if readers cared, they could find them.

Despite its unique structure, The Luminaries remains an exciting murder mystery with a captivating plot. Interestingly, Catton did not plan the story in advance. “I would try to write myself into a corner and then see how creative I could be in getting out of the situation I had created.” One of her goals was to make the book enjoyable for readers.

We also discussed her love for television dramas, noting how The Luminaries uses cliff-hangers, multiple viewpoints, and dialogue. I asked if she would be interested in screenwriting. “That could be pretty cool,” she replied, her enthusiasm evident.

She became animated when discussing her craft and New Zealand. “I notice that when I come to Britain, the landscape of my imagination changes just by being in a different place. I understand why writers leave New Zealand for more populated areas to experience the energy of other people.” For now, New Zealand will remain her home, and I hope it continues to inspire her for many more novels.

Text: 'As a boy, Jonny Kinkead spent his time either building things in his dad’s garage or playing the guitar. For the past forty years, he has made a living by handcrafting steel-string acoustic guitars. “I am still fascinated by the guitar,” he says. “How can two pieces of wood create such beautiful sounds? Different types of wood can produce different sounds, and that still amazes me.” Jonny learned to play his brother’s guitar when he was eleven. At sixteen, he wanted to learn the bass guitar. “Some people would get a part-time job to save for one,” he says. “But I believed that if you wanted something, you should make it yourself. I studied guitars to understand how different shapes and woods affect sound.” The bass guitar was the first instrument Jonny built from scratch, but he and his brothers had been making model boats and planes for a long time. “We drew designs and built them, so I was used to the process. My father taught us how to use tools like saws and chisels. I had also been customizing and repairing instruments for my friends.” Jonny’s bass guitar turned out well, but he hadn’t thought about a career in guitar-making yet. “I was also interested in painting and sculpture,” he says. After finishing school, he decided to study architecture at university because it involved design, which he liked. However, halfway through the course, he dropped out. “I was too independent for it,” he says. “But I left with a clearer idea of what I wanted to do. I realized that building guitars is a form of sculpture – it shapes sound. I thought it might be a more practical choice than pure art because you create things that people use.” Since then, Jonny has made guitars for a living. For the first ten years, he also cleaned windows part-time to earn extra money. The first guitars he sold were priced only to cover materials, but as he gained a reputation as a skilled guitar-maker, he could charge more. Even now, almost forty years later, Jonny says he is “still just getting by.” He admits he can only make about ten guitars a year, which limits his income. In the beginning, he focused on getting known. He attended music festivals most weekends to let musicians try his guitars and talk about him. He also had to learn how to price his instruments, as he was not naturally good at that. Jonny believes it is easier for new guitar-makers in the UK today. “When I started, many thought only American-made acoustic guitars were worth having,” he says. “UK-made guitars were not seen as real, even though we have always had good instrument-making courses and the skills have remained strong. Now, our handmade guitars have the reputation they deserve.” Jonny thinks valuable skills can be learned in classes, and he encourages new makers to take these courses. However, he also believes there is no substitute for learning through experience. “You should look at other instruments, see what works and what doesn’t, and try different things,” Jonny says. “If you make the back too thin or too thick, it won’t sound good. If you learn from someone else, you may only learn one method, but if you teach yourself, like I did, you learn everything.”'

Text: "When discussing English conversation, we often start with the weather. This is a common tradition, and I will reference the well-known statement by the 18th-century writer Dr. Johnson, who said, 'When two Englishmen meet, their first talk is of the weather.' This statement is still true today, just as it was over two hundred years ago. However, many people stop here or struggle to explain why the English seem so focused on the weather. They often make a mistake by thinking that when we talk about the weather, we are genuinely interested in it. 

For instance, the American writer Bill Bryson points out that English weather is not particularly interesting. He notes that in England, we do not experience extreme weather events like tornadoes or blizzards, which are common in other places. On the other hand, the English broadcaster Jeremy Paxman disagrees with Bryson, arguing that English weather is indeed interesting. He believes that the English fascination with the weather is not about strong feelings but rather about its unpredictability. He says that while we may not have tropical storms, living on the edge of an ocean means we can never be sure what the weather will be like.

From my research, I believe that both Bryson and Paxman miss the main point: our conversations about the weather are not really about the weather itself. Instead, talking about the weather is a way for English people to connect with each other. For example, phrases like 'Nice day, isn’t it?' or 'Ooh, isn’t it cold?' are not genuine questions about the weather; they are simply ways to start a conversation or fill silence. 

This type of weather talk is similar to 'social grooming' seen in monkeys and apes, who groom each other to bond socially. There are specific situations where weather talk is used. Some people say that the English talk about the weather all the time, but this is not accurate. In reality, there are three main contexts for weather talk: as a greeting, as a way to start a conversation, or as a fallback topic when other conversations pause. 

This does lead to a lot of weather talk, which makes it seem like English people are obsessed with it. A conversation might begin with a weather greeting, move to more weather talk to break the ice, and then return to weather talk when there is a lull in the conversation. This is why people from other countries, and even some English commentators, think that the English are very focused on the weather."

Alice Leader stood in front of Hadrian’s Wall in Britain, explaining to her class of 12- and 13-year-olds what an amazing engineering achievement it was for the Romans to build something 120 km long and 5 meters high about 1900 years ago. The students were interested in this trip, choosing it over exciting tours to Spain, Greece, or France. However, they wanted to know why the Wall was built, and Alice felt her answers were not good enough. Unable to find a suitable historical novel to help her explain life at the Wall during Roman times, she decided to write one herself. After retiring from teaching for 31 years, Alice began her new career as an author in 2001. Although she had a successful teaching career, she felt she was stepping into the unknown. “Teaching is like acting; it’s a performance every day and very physically demanding. Writing is exciting and a bit scary, but it’s not as tiring. My former teaching colleagues envy me because I still connect with children through my stories,” Alice says. 

Her main goal for her novels is to fill a gap in children’s fiction today. “Much of the young adult fiction now focuses on negative experiences. It is well written,” she adds quickly, “but a lot of it is dark reality, or it’s total fantasy, like Harry Potter. My books are neither.” Alice always tried to teach English and History together, such as lessons about ancient Greece alongside the novel Tale of Troy. She is motivated by her love for children. “I’m very interested in the moment when a child goes from being bored to interested, and then from not understanding to understanding. I love having bored children because that’s when the challenge begins. It’s up to me to make it work at that point.” She sees her writing as an extension of her teaching. 

Although she was inspired to write her first novel because she saw a gap in the market, the idea also came as her two sons were leaving home, and after her head teacher suggested she take a creative writing course. Alice was surprised. “I had been teaching for 25 years. She said it would be good for me, but I didn’t want to spend my summer holiday on a course I didn’t think I needed.” Before she could join the course, she had to send the tutors her best piece of fiction, which she learned about only a few days before leaving. “I sat down at the computer and quickly created a story about a Roman couple and their baby-to-be.” Three hours and 30 pages later, she sent it in and was accepted right away. During the course, the other students reviewed her work as it developed, gave her great feedback, and encouraged her to publish it. With only 8,000 report cards as proof of her writing ability besides that one story, she asked her school’s head teacher for a year off to write her first novel. 

Alice benefits from having her husband, critic and editor Zachary Leader, help her. His editing was crucial. Alice says, “My mother-in-law thinks we’re now rival authors, but I believe we complement each other. He works with what I’ve written – he reads a chapter and changes the sentence structure, and if it’s not working, he suggests different words. My instinct is to keep adding more scenes. That’s the difference between a fiction writer and an editor or critic.”

To raise money for charity, a newspaper and a TV company challenged brothers Jonny and Alistair Brownlee, who are champion triathletes, to participate in a special race. This race would have Jonny racing in a car on the roads, while Alistair would race on a mountain bike across the countryside. The race took place in the beautiful and rugged Yorkshire Dales in northern England. 

“I’m looking forward to it,” Jonny said as they prepared to start. “I’ve never done anything like this before; it’s exciting! The views here are beautiful, and it’s very cold, so I’ll be warm in the car.” Alistair was also eager, but he was dressed in full winter cycling gear, unlike Jonny, who wore jeans and a sweatshirt. “To be honest,” Alistair said, “I’ve seen Jonny drive before, so I’m not sure he’ll make it. I might stop for a cup of tea halfway up.”

The race began at Semerwater lake in Wensleydale and was to finish at Fleet Moss, Yorkshire’s highest road, which is about 350 meters high. This would be easy for the car, but Alistair faced a steep climb right from the start. After a quick handshake, they were off. Alistair sped away on his bike, heading straight up the hill, while Jonny got into his car and drove off. The question was, who would reach the finish line first?

Jonny’s confidence quickly faced a challenge. Just 15 seconds into his drive, he encountered a large tractor blocking the road. “Welcome to Yorkshire,” he complained to the cameraman in the car. “If Alistair beats me, it’s because of this farmer!” After getting past the tractor, Jonny continued driving, while Alistair struggled with the steep slope. A few miles in, he had to get off his bike and carry it up the hill, passing walls and fences. Sheep watched curiously as the Olympic champion walked with his bike on his shoulders. Finally, he reached the top. With the sun shining and open land ahead, he began to pick up speed.

In the car, Jonny faced another challenge. The narrow roads in this part of Yorkshire were not built for fast driving. He had to carefully navigate a very tight corner and then drive through a stream that had formed on the road. Once past the last village, he was on a straight path to the finish line. Neither brother knew how close the other was. As Jonny accelerated down the final stretch to Fleet Moss, Alistair was racing across his last field and back onto the road, approaching the finish from the other side. 

With his head down and legs pumping, Alistair reached the finish line and suddenly hit the brakes. He looked up and asked the crowd, “Is he here?” When they replied no, he raised his arms in celebration, shouting, “Yes!” Moments later, Jonny’s car arrived, and he stepped out. “Well done,” he said, feeling disappointed. “I’m gutted.”

Text: 'The silence is what you notice when you play on Centre Court at Wimbledon. You bounce the ball quietly on the soft grass; you toss it up to serve; you hit it and hear the echo of your shot. The trimmed grass, the rich history, the old stadium, the players in white, and the respectful crowds all create a calm atmosphere that protects you from the outside world. The quiet of Centre Court helps my game. What I struggle with most in a tennis match is to focus only on the game and the point I’m playing. The silence is broken by loud applause and cheers when a point ends. I hear them, but it feels distant. I don’t realize there are fifteen thousand people watching me closely, or that millions are watching around the world as I play Roger Federer in the 2008 Wimbledon final – the biggest match of my life. I had always dreamed of playing at Wimbledon. My uncle Toni, my coach, taught me from a young age that this was the most important tournament. By age 14, I was sharing my dream with friends that I would play there one day and win. Before 2008, I had played and lost to Federer twice – in the final the year before and the year before that. The loss in 2006 was not too hard. I was just happy to have made it that far after turning twenty. Federer won easily, more easily than if I had believed in myself more. But my loss in 2007 was devastating. I knew I could have played better; it was not my skill that failed me, but my mindset. I cried for half an hour in the dressing room after that loss. Losing always hurts, but it hurts more when you have a chance and lose it. Toni, my tough coach, usually doesn’t comfort me, even when I win. It shows how upset I was that he told me not to cry and that there would be more Wimbledons and finals. I told him he didn’t understand; I thought this was my last chance to win. I know how short a professional athlete's career is, and I want to make the most of it. Every moment matters, but some moments matter more, and I had let a big one slip away in 2007. There was nothing Toni could do to ease my sadness. But he was right in the end. Another chance came in 2008, just one year later. I was confident I had learned from my defeat; this time, my mindset would be strong. The best sign that I was focused was my belief that I would win. The night before the final, at dinner with family and friends, we didn’t talk about the match. I didn’t tell them not to mention it, but they understood that I was already preparing for the match in my mind. From that moment until the match started, that space in my mind was mine alone.'

Text: 'In early April 1957, a young and idealistic Englishwoman arrived in Africa. In her first letter home, she wrote, “I am living in the Africa I have always longed for.” Her name was Jane Goodall, and she would spend most of her life in Africa as a citizen, journalist, scientist, activist, and environmentalist. In 1963, the National Geographic Society in Britain helped make Jane Goodall famous by publishing articles and making documentaries about her research on chimpanzees. Her fame grew with her own writing, including popular children’s books and the 1971 bestseller In the Shadow of Man, which has been translated into 47 languages and is still available today. Jane Goodall is one of the most celebrated female scientists of the 20th century, second only to Marie Curie. However, her fame sometimes overshadows her real achievements. Many articles and interviews tell her life story, but they often focus on sentimental aspects. She has been portrayed as a little girl seeking adventure, a privileged woman wanting to live with wild animals, and a determined feminist in a male-dominated world. These portrayals can diminish her true contributions. 

Based on the number of academic references to her research, the success of her students in biology, and the extensive data from her forty-year study, Jane Goodall should be recognized as a pioneering zoologist. More simply, she opened our eyes to the social and emotional lives of chimpanzees. Before Goodall's work, people misunderstood the dangers of wild chimpanzees. No one knew that chimpanzees ate meat or that they used tools, like humans. We did not realize that chimpanzees share similar emotions with us or that their social structures are surprisingly similar to ours. We also learned that chimpanzee communities in Africa have unique cultural traditions. Goodall’s book, The Chimpanzees of Gombe (1986), is the most important work in this field and serves as the first encyclopedia for chimpanzee research. Her long-term study of wild chimpanzees in Gombe State, Nigeria, is considered one of the great scientific achievements of the Western world. Jane Goodall changed how we study animals, and since chimpanzees are our closest relatives, she also changed how we view ourselves.

Even as a child, there were signs of the person Jane Goodall would become. One clear example happened in the autumn of 1939 when she was just five years old. One day, Jane disappeared, and her family called the police to help find her. After a frantic search, she reappeared alone, with straw in her hair and clothes. Her mother asked, “Where have you been?” Jane explained that she wanted to know how hens lay eggs. To find out, she crawled into a henhouse, hid in the straw, and stayed still for five hours until a hen laid an egg. This moment can be seen as the start of her journey as a biologist.'

Text: 'In our first hour-long conversation, Shirley Ford talks to me using the voices of a playful 8-year-old boy, the boy’s tired mother, a funny elderly Scottish woman, and a very fast-talking alien. Her voices are familiar to viewers of children’s TV shows and cartoons, as well as people who have seen computer programs about health and safety. “I just did a voiceover about back injuries,” she says, “so I had to quickly learn how to pronounce many medical terms.” Shirley explains what it takes to do voiceovers. “Many actors, even well-known ones, think they can do funny voices, and many probably can,” she says. “But there’s more to it. You have to bring the script to life for an audience that can’t see you. You wouldn’t believe how many famous people want to do voiceover work. Producers invite them to auditions because of their fame, but often they don’t get the roles because they are too used to acting with their whole bodies.” 

After school, Shirley joined a drama course with the goal of having a standard acting career. During the course, she occasionally worked singing jingles for TV ads. “One day,” she says, “the man who ran the recording studio suggested I try out for the part of a rabbit in a cartoon soundtrack. It seemed silly – I hadn’t studied drama to play rabbits – but I tried it for fun and, surprisingly, got a major role.” Shirley discovered she could do voices and that voiceover work might be her path. “Things just happened for me,” she says. “In my second film, I was lucky to play the main character – and her brother and mother.” 

Adult female actors are often asked to provide the voices for young boys and girls. Their voices are lighter than those of male actors, and hiring child performers involves complex procedures and many forms, which production companies prefer to avoid. Shirley has learned to create the right sounds from the back of her throat, and to avoid always sounding like the same child, she collects new voices while watching children’s TV. Cartoons are the best part of a job that includes a variety of work from educational videos to vacuum cleaner ads. “Those are tough because you have to sound excited about something you don’t care about, but my years in this job help,” she says. “They’ve taught me that the trick is to smile while you talk – it makes your voice sound bright and cheerful. When I have days doing animation work, it feels like a holiday; the interaction with other actors makes a big difference.” 

The competition for work is strong, and a good showreel – a recording that shows what the artist can do – is very important. “It’s definitely worth investing in a strong showreel,” Shirley says. “There are agencies that help voiceover artists create them.” She believes she has reached her position – near the top of her field – through determination as much as talent. “Whether it’s making your showreel and taking it to all the film and TV companies, advertising agencies, and recording studios, or just practicing your voices, it’s all about setting goals and not giving up.” For anyone thinking about a career in voiceovers, Shirley suggests attending “specialist workshops – they cover all types of voiceover.” She also believes a love for human sound is essential, describing herself as obsessed with voices and, in a way, becoming the characters she performs. “If I’ve been in the studio doing a specific kind of American voice, for example, it can take over me and I’ll be speaking like that for hours, maybe even days afterwards,” she says. “My children have grown up used to their mom talking in completely different voices.”'

Text: 'People often ask me how I became a cartoonist. This is understandable because cartooning is a job many dream about as children, like being a race car driver. However, most people eventually give up these childhood dreams and think about more practical careers, like being a tax lawyer or making car parts. The idea that you can earn a living by drawing simple pictures, like those in the margins of school notebooks, seems silly. Yet, some people do just that. 

People become cartoonists in different ways, but most have wanted to do it for a long time. For me, I had a typical childhood for a cartoonist: I loved comic strips, contributed to school publications, and was known as ‘the kid who draws.’ I studied graphic design in college and, after graduating, I showed my illustrations to various companies. I was fortunate to find someone at a newspaper who needed political cartoons about local issues. I created a few ideas, and they bought them; soon, I was earning enough to support myself.

You don’t need much to become a cartoonist. You don’t need a university degree, a lot of money, or even to be a great artist. You just need your mind, your hand, and something to make marks with. However, if it were that easy, there would be as many cartoonists as there are teachers. While the technical skills needed to be a cartoonist are low, it is still a challenging job. No one should try to become a cartoonist unless they feel they cannot do anything else. It is much easier to get a regular job that pays the bills and allows time for family, home repairs, and hobbies.

The more skills you have, the better chance you have of making a living from your art. I have created political cartoons, comic strips, and comic books. I have also worked as a writer, caricaturist, and designer. I accept all kinds of work because you can learn a lot, even from jobs you don’t really want to do. It helps to be intelligent, well-read, and curious about the world.

What about the business side of being a cartoonist? There was a time when many cartoonists could find regular jobs with different newspapers and magazines. But those days are fading. For most people today, cartooning is an entrepreneurial activity, meaning you not only have to create the work but also sell it. The more comfortable you are with this, the more successful you will be. I have seen cartoonists with average creativity and strong business skills do much better than those who are very talented but lack other skills.

It surprises me how often I meet people who have never sold a cartoon but are afraid someone will steal their ideas. Some are so worried that they won’t even let others see their work! Legally, to protect your work, you just need to draw a small ‘c’ for ‘copyright,’ circle it, and write your name and the date next to it. But honestly, it is more likely that no one will be interested in your work. If someone does steal a cartoon and it becomes popular online, it is not a disaster – it could actually be a lucky break!'

Text: 'Twenty years ago, I was moving to a new house and cleaning out my things. Among other items, I decided to throw away an electric guitar that my dad had given me for my 16th birthday. It was a sleek, black guitar made in Japan. I usually hate getting rid of even useless items, so why did I want to throw this one away? I took it to the dump and was about to leave it on a pile of trash when a young man approached me, looking confused. “You’re not going to throw that away, are you?” he asked. I told him I was, and I started to feel regret. He asked if he could have it, and I said ‘Yes’. We then went our separate ways. In the days and years that followed, I felt a deep sadness for what I had done. A few months ago, I opened an email that changed my life. I remembered a story about a man who lost his wedding ring in the ocean; ten years later, he found it in a fish he was eating at a restaurant. That’s how I felt when I clicked on an email from someone I didn’t know, a guitar dealer and restorer named Keith Rushton. He wrote, “I’ve got your electric guitar.” It had been bought and sold many times since the young man at the dump took it. Keith found a name-and-address label on the back. He realized it was probably out of date but used my name to find me online. He eventually contacted me through the newspaper I work for and offered to sell it back to me. I was overwhelmed with emotion. I would have given him anything he asked for, but his price was very fair. I had forgotten that my dad always put name-and-address stickers on my things, including my guitar. My dad would have laughed at this strange situation! My parents wanted me to learn classical guitar because it was popular in the 1970s. I loved the sound of it: calming and gentle, and it was easier for beginners than the violin. However, I didn’t make much progress, so I switched to the electric guitar, playing simple songs. This was also the time of punk music, when people who couldn’t play well could still be rock stars. When I took my old guitar out of the box that Keith sent me, I suddenly remembered my birthday in 1978 when my smiling parents gave it to me. Holding it again, it felt smooth and smaller than I remembered. I sat down to play, but then I wanted to stand up and put a strap over my shoulder because electric guitars are played that way. My fingers knew where to go. I couldn’t have drawn a diagram for the chords I wanted to play, but my hands just remembered. My middle-aged fingers felt the familiar pain of pressing down the strings to play a chord. The electric guitar is not really a solo instrument. Now that I’m learning it again, I think I’ll need to form a band. My son is learning the saxophone; maybe we can play together. Or perhaps there are others my age who have had a similar experience. We could call ourselves ‘The Regainers’!'

Text: 

Recently, there has been much discussion about sleep. When I wrote the book *Insomniac*, which focuses on people who struggle with sleeplessness, I felt like I was one of the few warning about the dangers of not getting enough sleep and how it affects our minds, bodies, and emotions. Anyone who has insomnia will tell you that sleep is essential for our mental, physical, and social health. Interestingly, those who find it hardest to sleep often understand the importance of sleep the most. It is encouraging that sleep is finally receiving the attention it deserves. However, I wonder about dreams. There hasn’t been much talk about them. We often lose our dreams. When you wake up early due to an alarm, you miss out on the last hour or two of sleep, which is mostly REM (Rapid Eye Movement) sleep, the stage where we have the most dreams. Our most vivid and powerful dreams happen during REM sleep just before we wake up. A good sleeper spends about a quarter of their sleep time in REM, meaning that a person who lives to be 90 years old will spend around six or seven years in this stage. When researchers prevent people from experiencing REM sleep, they find that the next night, the amount and intensity of REM sleep increases to make up for it. This suggests that dreams serve a purpose. 

When REM sleep was discovered in 1953, many agreed with psychologist Sigmund Freud, who believed that understanding dreams was key to understanding our minds. However, later research did not support this idea, and the focus shifted to the physical reasons behind dreams rather than the psychological ones. Currently, there is little agreement among dream researchers, according to Harvard sleep scientist Robert Stickgold. 

Dreams are significant. At a meeting of the Associated Professional Sleep Society, P.F. Pagel from the University of Colorado Medical School shared a study showing that actors, writers, and directors remember and use their dreams much better than others. He concluded that the use of dreams increases with a person's interest in creativity. It makes sense that filmmakers have a strong connection to their dreams, as film is one of the most dream-like forms of human expression. However, I wondered if only creative people benefit from their dreams. Don’t teachers, software designers, and politicians also need to think creatively? 

Stickgold explains that dreams help us connect ideas in new and surprising ways, using knowledge from our past and present to create new associations. Dreams may help us discover new patterns and combinations that break our usual ways of thinking. For instance, Stickgold found that when people are woken from REM sleep and asked to respond to a specific word, their answers are more original than when they are woken from other sleep stages. They tend to "ignore the obvious" and combine ideas in unexpected ways, which is a form of creativity. 

I personally find that I write better after experiencing intense dreams. Even a difficult dream, or one that I can barely remember, seems to spark my thoughts. On those days, words and images flow so quickly that I can hardly keep up with my typing. I don’t fully understand how it works, but it does seem effective. 

Creativity is not just for writers or artists. We live in a complex world, and everyone needs their brains to function well. We must think creatively and flexibly as we interact with colleagues, family, and friends. This is why dreaming is important.

Text: 'Twenty years ago, Susie Ray left London to live in a small coastal town in south-west England. When you enter her studio, which has a stunning view of the sea, you see several empty frames on the walls, along with happy photos of her two daughters. As a leading artist in the copyist art movement, who can recreate the beauty of early 20th-century impressionist paintings and 16th-century Caravaggio portraits, it seems unusual that she has no paintings of her own. “I don’t keep any,” Susie says with a shrug. “As soon as I finish them, they go.” The reason is that Susie is in high demand. Over her 30 years as a copyist artist, she has painted works by many famous artists, including Renoir, Monet, and Van Gogh. Her reproductions are so accurate that art experts sometimes mistake them for the originals. While the original paintings could sell for millions at auctions, her copies sell for a few hundred pounds to £12,000, depending on how much time she spends on them. Susie does not reveal most of her clients, even when asked, but they include galleries and private collectors. While many collectors truly love art, some are more interested in status. One celebrity enjoys showing off his ‘Van Gogh’ painting, which is actually a ‘Susie Ray Van Gogh’. “Many famous people pass off my copies as originals,” she says. “That’s their choice.” Some collectors save on insurance by keeping the original in a bank safe and displaying Susie’s copy instead. Susie has always been honest about her work. When she copies an old masterpiece, she aims to make it look as real as possible, believing that doing a poor job would disrespect the original artist. However, she signs her name on the back of the canvas. Selling a copy as the real thing is illegal, and although she knows people who have profited from that, she has never been tempted. Those who create fakes often face serious consequences. Susie mentions that she isn’t wealthy and has faced challenges, but her situation is more stable now, and it wouldn’t be wise to risk her reputation with collectors and artists. Susie didn’t always work as a copyist. After earning her art degree, she worked as an illustrator for a botanical garden for several years, earning very little. Looking back, she sees that it helped her develop skills for her current work and sparked her love for plants, even though it was hard to make ends meet. She explains that she had to be very precise and get things right on the first try. She has no regrets about that time but is happy to have found a more financially rewarding career. When younger artists ask Susie for advice, she emphasizes the importance of learning to draw accurately. She also highlights how much she has studied to master her craft. Her training allows her to create everything from plant drawings to perfect copies of 15th-century masterpieces and 20th-century abstract art, although she now focuses on French impressionists, particularly Manet, Cezanne, and Degas. Susie notes that many people think modern art is simple, almost like child’s play. However, she believes that impressionists painted quickly and freely, but they were also very careful, making their work more challenging to replicate. Given her talent, it seems strange that Susie doesn’t create her own art. Isn’t art about self-expression? Could a Susie Ray original be worth more than a copy? She explains that her work is the result of years of training and dedication, and she earns a good living from it. She has tried creating her own pieces, like oil paintings of fishing nets, but they ended up looking like photographs—acceptable, but not impressive. Perhaps it’s like living on plain food after enjoying meals prepared by a top chef. The key thing about Susie is that she is a perfectionist.'

Text: 'During her racing days, Ellen MacArthur cared most about the sea and being the fastest on it. This passion started in her childhood. She had a unique bond with the boats that took her around the world; they felt like one entity. When she returned to land, everyday life seemed unimportant. People crowded around her, eager to hear about the race, but she quickly longed to be back on the ocean, challenging nature even in dangerous places. After finishing second in the Vendée Globe, a solo, non-stop round-the-world race, she showed me the small, stuffy cabin of her boat, Kingfisher. This was her home, workplace, and survival space for 94 days. She explained how she carefully planned her supplies, even counting the exact number of kitchen paper rolls she would need. Preparation was crucial, she said. She proudly displayed her unappealing stock of foil-wrapped, freeze-dried food, a tiny gas stove, and neatly organized medical supplies. Her attention to detail was as impressive as her sailing skills. The boat was her entire world, and she took care of it because her life depended on it. Now, she views the world as a boat: a small, beautiful, fragile thing with limited resources. 

Her perspective changed during a trip to South Georgia, a remote island in the South Atlantic, where she helped with a bird survey on albatrosses. ‘It made me stop and think. It gave me space to see things differently,’ she said. The many abandoned whaling stations served as a warning to her. ‘It felt like we just took what we wanted and moved on. That’s what we do.’ When I arrived at Ellen’s office, she was finishing a heated conference call. She then explained why we must act now to save the planet. ‘Coal, oil, and gas are no longer being made. They are precious resources we have only once. We need to find ways to not use them up. At first, my message was negative – use less – but I realized there is another way to look at things.’ Now she focuses on reusing materials, passionately discussing things like reusable industrial carpet tiles. For the past three years, she has been visiting factories, mines, and power stations, talking to governments and businesses about our dependence on non-renewable resources. ‘I will never be an expert,’ she says. ‘But I am like a sponge. I love soaking up information. The current situation is something I cannot ignore. Compared to sailing, this feels less selfish. It’s about finding how my voice can be most helpful. It really matters.’ She also started the Ellen MacArthur Foundation, a charity that works with businesses and schools to inspire young people to rethink and redesign a sustainable future. ‘I do miss the adventure of being at sea,’ she admits. ‘It defines who I am. You feel connected to everything around you. You don’t have time to feel lonely. You focus on records, practical matters, and survival. My new message is not as simple as saying: “I’m going to be the fastest around the world.” I may have been the fastest, but this work is more important than anything I’ve ever done.’

Text: 'Jordan Romero is 13 years old and wants to be the youngest person to climb Mount Everest. If he succeeds, he could become one of the most famous teenagers of his time. He hopes to inspire other kids to explore the outdoors instead of just playing on computers and video games. Jordan's climbing team includes his father, Paul, and mother, Karen. They call themselves "Team Romero," and climbing Everest is just part of their goal. If Jordan climbs Everest and Vinson Massif in Antarctica, he will be the youngest person to have climbed the Seven Summits, which are the highest mountains on each continent. Very few people achieve this before the age of thirty. Jordan has already climbed five of them and might complete the challenge before he turns 20.

I spoke to several experienced Everest climbers, and none thought it was a good idea to take a 13-year-old up the highest mountain in the world. They agreed that a young climber might be physically strong, but they were unsure if a teenager would be emotionally strong enough. They also questioned whether a young person could have enough experience to make good decisions and react properly in dangerous situations.

The Romeros have heard these opinions before. Paul says, "I know there is criticism, but I can’t focus on it – there’s still so much to do. I think about possible problems, of course. Karen and I consider the risks all the time, but we believe our experience as climbers will help. Watching Jordan grow gives me confidence. He’s becoming very strong and mature."

I also wonder about Jordan’s reasons for wanting to climb. Is this just an ambitious father pushing his son too far? Paul insists, "This project isn’t about me trying to gain fame through my son’s achievements. At first, Jordan thought about doing it later in life, but we discussed it and decided: ‘Why not now?’ We talk to him often to ensure he still wants to do it."

When I ask Jordan what he enjoys about the challenge, he says, "I just focus on achieving my goal." In the past, few people cared about being the youngest or fastest to climb a mountain or sail an ocean. Today, every adventure is shared online, and every climb becomes a record-setting event. The more exciting the record, the more interest it creates. This puts Jordan in a difficult position. We often say that achieving goals can take away from the enjoyment of the experience, but if Jordan wants to inspire others, he must engage with the media. This means blogging, taking photos, and giving interviews. He needs to offer something impressive, like climbing Everest.

Paul adds, "If Jordan comes home tomorrow and says he’s done with mountain climbing and wants to play basketball instead, we will stop this project and go to the gym."

Bonnie Wyndham stepped out of her mother’s car and looked at Almonside School. “I’ll make you regret I came here,” she said to the school, with a smile. Her mother was getting out of the other side and didn’t hear her, but Bonnie wouldn’t have minded if she had. Her mother understood how Bonnie felt. Mrs. Wyndham looked around. Almonside was an unusual school, with buildings hidden among the trees on a hillside; it was quite confusing at first. Then she saw the signs: Science block, gymnasium, riding centre… “Riding centre,” Bonnie said, suddenly interested. “Headmaster’s study,” her mother replied. “This way.” Bonnie followed her mother along a wide path that curved between the trees. “I wish you’d walk next to me instead of behind me like a dog,” Mrs. Wyndham said tiredly, but she didn’t seem to expect Bonnie to do so. A few minutes later, her mother was talking to Bonnie’s new headmaster in his study, while Bonnie waited outside the door. Suddenly, Bonnie stood up. “Why should I just sit here?” she thought. “I’ll be kicked out soon anyway, so why not get it over with?” She left the building and went towards the riding centre, following the sign. There was a nice old building for the horses and a large indoor riding area. Bonnie looked around, but there was no one in sight. She approached the horses with respect. They were well cared for, and she could see that right away. Almost every stall was occupied, and she walked along, carefully observing each horse. “I know what you’re doing here,” she said to a small pony, gently touching its nose. The next horse caught her attention. “But aren’t you the best of them all!” she exclaimed. He was brown with a bit of white. He looked lively, which Bonnie liked. “I feel like we’ve met before,” she said, stroking his neck. “In my dreams, I was riding you to victory in a big competition…” Above the stall was his name: Maverick. Suddenly, she couldn’t resist the urge to ride him. “I wonder where I can find a bridle and a saddle. It can’t be far.” Bonnie was happy to find that the room with the riding equipment was unlocked. Lost in the joy of putting a saddle on Maverick, she forgot all about her mother and the headmaster. When she climbed onto the big horse outside, she felt like a queen, in control of everything she could see. Her nickname at her old school had been Queen Bee, and she laughed as she remembered it. “You’re the best horse I’ve ever ridden, Maverick,” she said with admiration. “I’m serious, I know about horses, even if I don’t know much else.” She nudged him into a walk, then a trot. “If I stay here, I think we could be great friends,” she said. She rode around the paddock. The rhythm was exciting, with a light breeze brushing past her cheek. She could tell Maverick trusted her, and she felt sure he would jump well.

Text: 'I have met Cody Simpson before and have always admired his quiet confidence. The 15-year-old Australian has already released many successful songs. So how did a relaxed surfer end up performing on stage in front of thousands of fans? “I first picked up a guitar when I was six and started writing songs at seven,” Cody recalls, explaining how it all began. “But I was swimming and surfing every day. Those activities were more important to me back then; I had my life set up and was busy. When I was 13 and in high school, I posted a few videos online.” These videos changed everything. He started by sharing a video of himself and a friend singing at a school concert. Fans commented online, asking for more videos. So, Cody, who had recorded more at home, was happy to share. The responses were overwhelming. Cody was also a talented swimmer. He trained hard with top coaches and focused on perfecting his sport. But then record labels contacted him, and he faced a tough choice: stay in Australia and continue swimming or take a big risk by signing a deal and moving with his family to the US. Cody decided to take the plunge. “It was very difficult for me – especially at such a young age – to choose a career. Can you imagine being 12 or 13 and trying to figure out what you want to do for the rest of your life?” He had to tell his swimming coach and friends that he was moving to the States. “It surprised most people. I’m kind of the quiet kid,” he remembers, thinking of their shocked faces. “I’m very modest, and I think it’s important to stay that way in this crazy industry.” So Cody packed his bags and moved with his family across the world, giving up one dream to pursue another. Although his family stays out of the spotlight and isn’t directly involved in his career, they support him from the background. Cody believes it’s important to have a close circle of good people around you to stay grounded. Of course, everyone has days of doubt. “Sometimes when I’m alone, I think, ‘How did my decision affect my little brother and sister?’ My little brother is eight, and he’s traveling the world, doing school on the road; he doesn’t have a normal life,” Cody admits. “I worry about how that affects him, but my family always reassures me that they support and encourage me in everything I do.” Success in any career comes from being willing to say ‘yes’ to your big break, even when it’s a bit scary. “It all happened so fast and unexpectedly,” Cody says. “Now, I’m visiting countries I never thought I would see and playing in front of hundreds of thousands of fans – it’s something many people dream of achieving. But I know it won’t last forever.”'

Text: 'I jumped out of bed, pulled back a corner of the bedroom curtain, and looked down at the river bend. A new crack in the ice sparkled in the morning sunlight. I shaded my eyes and looked upstream at the wall of sandbags, which were there to protect the buildings from flooding as the river ice melted. My back still hurt from lifting them into place. Last week, I had worked with most of the town’s adults for long hours, showing that I could handle the job. My grandfather didn’t seem to notice. With one hand still on the curtain, I looked along the half-mile stretch of steaming black water created by the release pipe from the wood processing factory in Milltown. There were fragile ice shelves on either side, and the dark open water was followed by solid ice downstream. As I took off my pajamas and reached for my kayaking wetsuit, I saw a boy on the far side of the river. I didn’t recognize him. I frowned. Amazingly, he was trying to balance on an ice shelf near the warm water from the factory. I zipped up my wetsuit and grabbed my kayaking jacket. I checked the pocket for my lucky chain – a silver chain my famous grandfather brought back from an expedition in South America. This chain is much better than having a famous grandfather, and only he, my mom, and I know about it. I also have the actual diary he kept on that trip. I keep it under my pillow and read it before I sleep. I touched the chain again and went to the kitchen. ‘Morning, Rex.’ Mom smiled at me as I took a banana from the counter. ‘You’re up early for a Saturday. I’ll make brunch after your training session. Be careful.’ ‘Thanks, Mom.’ I walked down the hallway and almost bumped into Grandpa as he stepped out of his bedroom. ‘Can’t you watch where you’re going?’ he shouted. ‘Where are you going?’ ‘Sorry, Grandpa. I’m going kayaking.’ As if my wetsuit didn’t make that clear. As if he didn’t see me in my kayak every morning. Grandpa is Grandpa, and I try to ignore it when he gets angry, but it’s been harder lately. ‘What’s the point of training? You didn’t win the competition,’ he said. For a moment, his harsh words hit me hard. But I took a deep breath and counted to three. He crossed the hall and slammed the bathroom door. Mom came in with a sympathetic smile. ‘Don’t mind him. He’s…’ ‘…not himself right now,’ I finished for her. I held back from saying he had always been that way. But, like Mom, I try to be kind to him. When I was a child, he was my hero – from the time he first showed me photos of himself in National Geographic magazine. Those old photos still hang framed on his bedroom wall, above his dusty medals and trophies. But I don’t go into his room anymore. I have my own growing collection of trophies to look at and, maybe soon, my own face in National Geographic. Yet, a part of me still wants to stay loyal to him, this grumpy old man. Mom smiled. ‘At least he’s coming out of his bedroom more. Have a good session, Rex. I admire your determination to keep going, even on these cold days!’ I smiled back at her as I peeled my banana. ‘It’ll be warmer in South America,’ I said. ‘If I find sponsors for my expedition.’ She laughed and went back to the kitchen. I ate my banana and went downstairs. Stepping into the backyard, I hurried towards the boathouse.'

Text: 'Mum grabbed Jess by the arm. “Come with me,” she said. Jess followed her into the study, where on the table, leaning against the wall, was an unframed painting. It was clearly one of Grandpa’s works, but it looked different from his usual style and was obviously unfinished. “Do you know anything about this?” Mum asked. Jess shook her head. “I’ve never seen it before. I didn’t know he was working on anything.” Jess looked closely at the painting. There was a river that took up most of the scene; it was not a river she recognized and might not even be real, just a made-up river. The painting was strange and unclear – yet beautiful in a haunting way. The riverbank was almost unnoticeable, with just a hint of green that the eye barely registered, as it was drawn into the pale waters leading to a hidden sea. There were no animals, birds, or people; and it felt right that way. There seemed to be no place for living things in this distant image. Yet for some reason, she was fascinated, thinking about autumn coming after a long, warm summer. Mum spoke again. “It has a name.” There was something in her voice – too casual and detached – that showed her excitement. Jess understood why. Grandpa never named his paintings. He just painted them and let others interpret them, if they could. Mum turned the painting over and pointed to the words Grandpa had written there. Jess read them aloud. “River Boy.” The words felt strangely significant to her, but she couldn’t explain why. There was another mystery. She looked at Mum. “There is no boy.” “Exactly. Strange, isn’t it – for him to be so specific. Still, he hasn’t finished it yet, so maybe he will add the boy later. I made the mistake of asking him about it.” “Mum! You should have known better.” “I know, but I couldn’t help it. It’s such an unusual painting, especially with a name. I guess you can imagine his response.” Jess didn’t need to guess. She knew what Grandpa would have said. “He told you it’s not the artist’s job to explain a painting because each picture has its own life and language, just like a poem, and we either understand it or we don’t. And he said painting is hard enough work without having to waste time explaining it to every fool…” “Ignoramus, he said.” “...every ignoramus what it means. And if artists had to explain their paintings to every Tom, Dick, and Harry who came along, they’d never get any work done. And he said…” Mum interrupted her, laughing. “Something like that. Anyway, I was hoping you might know something about this painting, since you seem to inspire him.” “Inspire?” “Someone who motivates an artist.” She knew what the word meant. Grandpa often used it when she watched him paint, but usually, it was just to say that the muse wasn’t being kind to him that day or that he needed to be nice to the muse because he had a tough part to work on. He never suggested the muse was about her. In fact, she always thought he meant some kind of goddess, not a real person. It was hard to imagine anyone, even a goddess, influencing someone as stubborn as Grandpa. “He doesn’t need me to inspire him,” she said. “He’s been painting all his life.”'

Text: 'When I woke up this morning, I didn’t plan to cut a hole in my bedroom carpet. I’m not saying it was an accident, but it could have been. For example, if I had tripped over the bed with Dad’s Stanley knife in my hand, the blade might have gone into the carpet and made a big hole. That is something that could have happened. I’m not saying it did, just that it could have. I didn’t mean to damage the carpet. I didn’t wake up thinking, ‘Today I will cut a hole in my carpet.’ It just seemed like a good idea at the time, as things often do. Later, you wonder why you thought that, but by then it’s too late. This happens to me quite often. I’m a bit unlucky in that way. 

What I was really doing was trying to fit my corner cabinet into a corner. Gran gave me the cabinet when she moved to a flat. It’s very cute! It’s small, painted white, with pink and blue flowers around the edge, and tiny glass doors. Gran used to keep china ornaments in there: shepherdesses, milkmaids, and old-fashioned ladies selling balloons. I keep my collection of shells, fossils, and interesting stones there. Gran knew I loved her corner cabinet, and I was so happy when she gave it to me! 

But the cabinet is a corner cabinet, which means it is shaped like a triangle. It has to stand in a corner. I only have two corners in my bedroom because it’s the smallest room in the house, tucked under the roof, and shaped like a wedge of cheese. The big front bedroom is Mum and Dad’s; the one at the back is my sister Angela’s; the little one over the garage is my brother Tom’s; and the tiny one that is the size of a broom cupboard is mine. Mum says that when Angela goes to university, Tom can have her room, and I can have his. And when Tom goes to university, I can choose any room. But since Angela is only fifteen, it seems I will be stuck in my broom cupboard for a long time. 

I don’t really mind; I quite like my little bedroom. It’s cozy, like a nest. I love the way the roof slopes down and the window is at floor level. The only problem is the lack of corners! My bed is in one corner, and my wardrobe is in the other. I tried to fit Gran’s cabinet into the space between the roof and the floor, but it was just a little too tall. If I could only cut a couple of centimeters off the bottom of it... That was when I had an idea. If I couldn’t cut anything off Gran’s cabinet, how about cutting a hole in the carpet? It seemed like the obvious solution. What Dad calls lateral thinking. I thought he would be pleased with me. He always tells us to ‘think outside the box’. And that was exactly what I was doing!'

Text: 'The novel ‘The Borrowers’ tells the story of a family of tiny people who live secretly in the walls and floors of a house, borrowing things from normal-sized people to survive. When I was asked to direct a TV adaptation of the novel, I knew it would be challenging to meet people’s expectations. Fans of the book have strong opinions about how it should be portrayed. I relied on the original illustrations from the book because I wanted to avoid criticism for getting it wrong. The author wanted the series to show the Borrowers' point of view, not that of humans, which made filming more complicated. 

The most important aspect was getting the scale right. The Borrowers are ten times smaller than humans, so when we filmed them walking across a room or going on borrowing missions, we had to position the camera ten times further away than usual. To capture the Borrowers' perspective, the crew had to crawl on the ground and film from no higher than 15 centimeters. They went through many pairs of jeans! We only raised the cameras for aerial shots. 

A major challenge was creating realistic shadows when combining images of the tiny Borrowers with the normal-sized surroundings. We developed a special technique for this. After the series aired, the famous US director George Lucas called to ask how we achieved it. The only permanent set we built was the Borrowers' home under the floorboards, filled with oversized objects to make the actors appear small. It was wonderfully surreal. I remember asking them to carry giant scissors, and they really embraced the idea. The coins were particularly memorable; they were larger than dinner plates and hard to lift, often making the crew laugh so much that we had to pause filming. 

In the story, there is a scene where the Borrowers are swept down a drain. To film this, the actors had to be pushed down a tunnel with hoses, and they found it so frightening that they didn’t need to act. One important aspect for me, which other directors have struggled with, was getting the costumes right. I had them made from heavy canvas so they would stick out like dolls' clothes. This made it very difficult for the lead actress to move; she couldn’t sit down during breaks and had to be sewn into her dress every morning. The lead actor's trousers were made from a rug because normal fabric would have looked too smooth. Unfortunately, it was very hot during filming, and I don’t think they appreciated my attention to detail with the costumes!

Most of the action away from the Borrowers’ home was filmed with the actors in front of a blue screen on an empty set. It was challenging for them to react to things that weren’t physically there. I had to draw pictures of each scene to show how they should look – I ended up with 2,000 drawings. They weren’t precise, but they were helpful. The budget didn’t allow for time in special effects studios during the day, so I worked nights for three months. We had to work quickly – I once filmed an entire scene before realizing there was no film in the camera. But everything came together in the end, and I believe the series successfully captured the magic of the books.'

Text: "Mom stops the car at the corner of my new school, Palm Grove High School. She looks around nervously, searching for journalists that aren’t there. I wonder how long it will take before the chaos starts. It always does. The fake smiles, the people who want to be my friends, and the ones asking for free tickets to my dad’s concerts. ‘Everything will be fine,’ I tell her. She kisses her fingertip and touches my cheek before I get out of the car. Then she drives away, leaving me alone in this new school and situation. But this is what I wanted. I wanted to escape my old life on the road with tour tutors. While the rest of the band is renting here for recording, we are staying for good. I insisted on coming to this school because I want to meet regular kids. How about a kid with a mom who works in an office or a dad who mows lawns? That would be so cool. 

I walk into the school’s main office. ‘Hi, I need my schedule, please,’ I say to the school secretary. ‘Name?’ She looks as friendly as an ice bucket. ‘Desert McGraw.’ ‘Desirée?’ she asks, leaning closer. ‘Desert,’ I repeat. The secretary seems confused. ‘Oh,’ she says and types ‘McGraw’ on her keyboard. That’s one good thing. Few people recognize my last name because my dad uses his stage name. ‘What grade?’ ‘Eleventh.’ ‘One moment, it’s printing,’ the secretary says. Then she rips the sheet and hands it to me. English Literature, first period. Great, I can handle that. English has always been my favorite subject. I’ll be late, though. English is in Room 214, on the second floor. I studied the map the night before so I wouldn’t look foolish searching for my classes. 

When I reach the door, I hear the teacher taking attendance. ‘Aurelio Gonzalez.’ ‘Here.’ She continues while I slip in quietly and sit at the last desk in the second row. The girl next to me smiles. Her eyes scan my very normal and, I must say, clever outfit – jeans and a T-shirt. Ha! Nobody will suspect me now! ‘Nice shoes,’ she whispers. I look down at my expensive shoes with tan embroidered flowers. Oh no, I knew I shouldn’t have worn these. ‘Thanks,’ I say. The teacher pauses in the attendance. ‘Desert... McGraw?’ she says hesitantly. ‘Here.’ The teacher smiles and introduces herself as Ms. Smigla. She talks a lot and eventually gives us our course outlines. After we review them and she tells us about the books we need to read this year, she actually gives us time to socialize! All teachers should understand how important this is. 

‘So why did you move here?’ my new friend asks. I have many options. Do I say it’s because I wanted a normal life away from cameras, reporters, and the red carpet? Or the real reason, according to Dad? ‘We need a change, Desert,’ he said, ‘and this is the perfect place to record the new album. Energy, color, culture... just what our last album needed.’ Personally, I think he just wants to relax on the beach. Why else would they choose South Beach Sounds, a recording studio two steps from the sand? ‘My dad had to move,’ I tell her. Yes, lies work better. ‘What does he do?’ she asks. Oh, whatever. Everyone will find out eventually. But at least I’ll have some time to pretend to be normal until they do. ‘He’s an artist,’ I say, playing with the zipper on my backpack. ‘Cool. I’m Becca, by the way.’ And she doesn’t seem to care. Great."

Text: 

Today, American teenage girls are expected to be Student Council presidents, have part-time jobs, volunteer, and excel in all these areas. This is what it means to be a teenager in America now. Both boys and girls cannot just go to school and be average; mediocrity is not acceptable, and lacking ambition is seen as laziness. Teenager Kristen Loose explains, “People, often adults, forget how much pressure teenagers face today. We have a lot of homework, tests, extracurricular activities, jobs, chores, and responsibilities at home, all while trying to maintain a social life.” 

Despite these pressures being common, negative stereotypes about teenagers still exist, often spread by the media. These stereotypes include being lazy, disrespectful, rebellious, loud, reckless, and self-centered. While some teenagers may fit these descriptions, many believe it is unfair to label the entire generation this way. Loose points out that many people think teenagers spend most of their time watching TV or using their phones. She acknowledges that she often has her cellphone nearby, but she uses it for more than just texting friends. It is a tool that helps teenagers manage their lives. 

Today, students are expected to have quick access to information and be reachable at all times, which can create the impression of cellphone addiction. With smartphones, tablets, and social media, students can do their homework anywhere. Instead of just listening to music on the way to school, they might listen to language lessons. Schoolwork and other activities now require attention around the clock, adding to the stress of already busy teenagers. Many teenagers start their days around 6 a.m. or 7 a.m. and often finish after midnight, balancing school, activities, family duties, and homework. They often get less than the recommended nine hours of sleep each night. 

The US National Sleep Foundation found that only about 20 percent of American teenagers get the recommended amount of sleep. Additionally, 28 percent of teens admitted to falling asleep in school about once a week due to lack of sleep. Teenager Lindamarie Olsen believes that after all her activities, she has about 18 hours of free time each week. With 168 hours in a week, 18 hours is not much. Olsen rarely spends this time on social media or TV; instead, she dedicates it to volunteer work. She says, “People think teenagers only care about themselves and their own interests.” However, Olsen enjoys volunteering and looks forward to making a positive impact in her school and community. 

In 20 years, the stereotype of teenagers may change, but they will continue to challenge these views and make a difference in the world. There will always be a new generation of students who are making their mark before they even finish school.

Text: 'The teenage members of the Earth to Sky Calculus Club live in and around Bishop, a mountain town in the US, surrounded mostly by wilderness, east of the Sierra Nevada mountains. In recent years, this small group has launched over fifty balloons to the edge of space, about 35 km above the Earth. This ongoing science project is both an astronomy experiment and an outdoor adventure, which may be why teenagers join. I visited them one weekend in late spring. They were about to release a high-altitude balloon to capture images of shooting stars. Shooting stars happen when a rock or piece of metal from space enters the Earth's atmosphere, creating a bright trail of light. As it got dark, the teenagers attached a soft insulated $5 lunch box to the bottom of the balloon. Inside were a camera, an altitude measuring device, and a thermometer to check temperature changes during the ascent. Two GPS trackers were placed on the outside of the lunch box to help the group find it later. A gas tank, given by a supporter from a nearby state, was used to inflate the balloon, which slowly grew to the size of a small car. An older boy made a seven-hour round trip to get it. ‘I didn’t really mind,’ he said. For kids in this club, that’s normal. Finally, it was time for lift-off. ‘Five, four, three, two, one,’ they counted down, and the balloon began to rise. Some of them ran and followed its path with bright flashlights for as long as they could, lighting up the balloon in the dark sky. There was silence and a strong feeling of wonder. Then the balloon vanished into the night. After the launch, most students went home, but a few stayed to watch the shooting stars. They lay on blankets on the mountainside, looking at a sky so clear that it was hard to believe they were only four hours from Los Angeles, a busy city with around 4 million people. I saw a boy climb into a sleeping bag and quickly fall asleep. ‘We're the only ones talking,’ said one girl quietly. ‘I know,’ whispered another. A meteor streaked across the sky. As the balloon rose, the air pressure decreased, causing the balloon to expand until it was almost the size of a house. Then it popped with a loud bang. A parachute helped the lunch box land safely back on Earth. The students would find it the next day using the GPS trackers. Retrieving it wasn’t easy, but that was part of the fun. There is little inhabited land around Bishop, so the lunch box usually lands in remote areas. ‘To me, recoveries are a big part of the program,’ said the group’s leader, noting they’ve lost only two lunch boxes in 53 launches. ‘Part of the journey has been getting to know this landscape in a way you normally wouldn’t.’ This time, the lunch box landed 84 km west of Bishop, but to reach it, the recovery team had to drive south of the Sierra and then back up the western side of the mountains. They also had to decide whether to drive or walk, as it could be dangerous if the lunch box was on a high peak or in a tall tree. ‘It’s important to remember that these students are from the Eastern Sierra,’ their leader said. ‘What may seem wild and dangerous to some is just a way of life for others.’ In the end, it took them 11 hours to find the lunch box. It was in a canyon, on a flat rock, near a waterfall. The camera hadn’t captured any shooting stars. While this was a bit disappointing, it also provided a chance to discuss the effects of atmospheric waves and how they might behave above mountain ridges. And it was one more adventure story to share with anyone who asked.'

Text: Chloe Morgan admits that science, especially Palaeontology, did not interest her much until she was fifteen. It was more of an accident than a plan. "My younger brother was going through a dinosaur phase, which I had not experienced. I usually dismissed it. I helped him with a science project, and when I found an article about recent discoveries in Palaeontology, it amazed me. I knew right away that I wanted to pursue this field."

I am curious about the support she received, as Palaeontology was not a common career choice for young people back then. "I remember meeting my first professional palaeontologist," she laughs. "Matt Cornelius was already famous, even though he was young. I was very nervous, even though he was known for being friendly. I worried he would think I was just an annoying kid asking too many questions. It could have been awkward," Chloe says. "But I felt more comfortable when he showed patience and listened to me."

I ask her about how palaeontologists are shown in movies and TV shows. Chloe frowns for a moment. "I have to admit that films like Jurassic Park, which feature dinosaurs created with special effects, have increased public interest in these creatures, but not necessarily in Palaeontology itself. While I appreciate this interest, I think the few palaeontologists shown in films are often portrayed inaccurately. It bothers me that we are either seen as eccentric geniuses or as socially awkward people who cannot connect with others. Movies do not accurately represent our daily work life."

I ask her to explain her job. "My work is very varied. I spend a lot of time digging up dinosaur bones, but I also work long hours in laboratories, analyzing fossils and writing for scientific journals." Although it is not something she does every day, she also communicates scientific findings to the public when she can. She takes this role seriously. "There are many misunderstandings about science, and while some colleagues do not want to be distracted from research, I believe it is important to address these issues. I want to reach out to young people because it is essential to inform them about all aspects of science. Talking about dinosaurs can inspire children to learn about the natural world and explore other areas of science."

The recent TV documentary Walking with Dinosaurs gave Chloe a chance to influence how dinosaurs are shown on screen. She emphasizes that the creators of the program knew what they were doing, and she was there to offer advice if needed. "I had an easy time because there was little I needed to correct, like dinosaurs that were too large or the wrong shape; mostly, I checked that the dinosaurs shown lived during the same time period. We attracted audiences of all ages because we have learned so much about dinosaurs recently, and the ones in this program are very different from those in movies like Jurassic Park. They are the most realistic representations ever made."

Why does Chloe think dinosaurs continue to fascinate us and remain a focus of research? "I believe they appeal to our natural curiosity. Our imaginations are drawn to the unknown and the idea of discovery. In a world that seems to be getting smaller, prehistoric creatures remind us that there is still much to explore. Palaeontology is like a form of time travel."

Text: "I will say this once: when you are traveling by car with your family, even if you are six years old, you know that you are not ‘there yet,’ even when you keep asking, ‘Are we there yet?’ The truth is, once you arrive, it’s not ‘there’ anymore; it’s ‘here.’ So if you think you might be ‘there’ already, you should be asking, ‘Are we here yet?’ I’m sure no one wishes to be ‘there yet’ more than the parents who hear that question over and over on long car trips. 

Think about it. Wouldn’t you rather relax in the back seat, with no responsibilities? You could watch DVDs, listen to music, or do puzzles while enjoying the beautiful views outside. In the front seat, there’s a parent with a map, giving out juice boxes and cookies, adjusting the radio, and making sure everything runs smoothly.
