But then, someone in the car does something annoying—usually my younger brother, Tim. He might put his foot on my side of the seat. I can’t let that happen, so I put my foot on his side. Soon, he’s all over my space, and a fight starts. The driver and the other parent have to reach back to separate us while the car swerves. They tell Tim to stay in his seat and keep his hands to himself. This calms things down for a bit, and we continue to see the beautiful scenery.

Then, while I’m trying to read, I feel a draft on my arm. The window isn’t open, so where is it coming from? Tim is next to me, quietly blowing his breath in my direction. He’s not touching me, so he thinks he’s being clever. This makes me angry. Tim gets yelled at again, and the car swerves more. Eventually, things calm down again.

Over the years, Dad has come up with ways to handle us in the back seat. When we ask, ‘Are we there yet?’ he often replies, ‘Yes, we’re here. Get out of the car.’ But we are still on the highway, going 70 miles an hour. Then he says, ‘Oh, maybe we’re not there yet.’ This keeps us quiet for a while. 

You can tell when you finally arrive because the adults jump out of the car and move as far away from us as possible after all those hours. So remember: if Mom and Dad are still close enough to answer your question, then the answer is: no, you’re not there yet."

Text: 'John and Zuzi Morgan have opened a café in Oxford, UK, where people can enjoy coffee and cake while playing board games. The owners hope that customers will love the experience and want to come back. Zuzi explains their motivation for starting this business: “There is so much technology today. Everyone is busy with their mobile phones and gadgets. We wanted to bring people together in a way that doesn’t involve staring at screens. It’s natural for people to connect and communicate.” The games played in their café are called ‘Eurogames’. These games often have gentle themes, like farming and building landscapes. The first Eurogame was The Settlers of Catan, created by German designer Klaus Teuber. In this game, players build settlements on an island and trade resources, keeping everyone engaged until the end, so no one feels left out. This idea was improved in ‘co-operative’ games, where all players either win or lose together, encouraging more social interaction. Pandemic, a Eurogame where players work together to solve global problems, was created by North American designer Matt Leacock, who is very successful in the board game world. He was inspired by a Eurogame called Lord of the Rings, based on the famous book. Leacock recalls, “When I played that with friends, we felt scared and excited. In the end, everyone felt good, whether they won or lost. I wanted to create something like that.” Leacock’s love for board games started when he was a child. “Games were my favorite birthday gift,” he says, “but I would get very excited, open the box, and then feel disappointed when we played.” With help from his game-loving uncle, young Leacock would change the games they played to try to make them better. Pandemic became a huge success, and its follow-up version advanced game design even further. Leacock explains, “It has a lot of storytelling. It’s like a video game where you develop characters, get new rules, and the world changes. It tells a story.” Surprisingly, the growth of the video game industry has helped the success of modern board games. Many people now have game consoles and play mobile games, making game-playing more common. Ben Hogg, who works for a leading games company, says, “Video games and board games have learned a lot from each other. Everyone plays games on their smartphones now. More people are open to playing games than ever before.” For a while, video games allowed some social interaction, like at arcades or multiplayer games played in the same room. But then, many multiplayer games moved online, making players physically distant from each other. As a result, some people who enjoyed video games began to seek ways to play games with others in person again. In John and Zuzi's busy café, tabletop gaming has become more than just entertainment. In our increasingly online world, games are now something to be shared directly and physically, and this trend is likely to continue.'

Text: Jamie Scott has written and produced many popular songs in the UK in recent years. His story shows that endurance and persistence are important in the music industry, even if your career starts with many challenges. He mentions that his mother was a great singer and helped him learn the guitar. The only radio station he listened to at home was for middle-aged people, which influenced his musical taste as he grew up. He was 12 years old when he first heard a modern song. Around the same time, he had to choose between playing tennis, which he did at a national level, and music. He spent his lunchtimes in the school music room learning songs on the piano. He said, “I was doing well in tennis, but it was not what I wanted to do for my life. It was just too much hard work.” At 17, he left school to pursue a career as a performer. He formed a duo with a friend who was a good guitarist but did not share his passion for performing. Jamie recalls, “I went to my parents and broke down. I told them I wanted to do this, that I had been writing lyrics in economics class and playing the piano every day while others were outside.” His father gave him 18 months to succeed; if he didn’t, he would need to find a job. After several close calls with record labels, he was signed to a music publisher at 19 based on one song. However, record labels wanted him to be a solo artist, so he had to part ways with his friend. Ultimately, he found success behind the scenes rather than on stage. After a tough time with a UK record label, he asked to leave and joined another label to release a new album. However, fame did not come easily. He said, “In my own artist career, I feel like I’ve been in the wrong place at the wrong time. But as a writer, I’ve been in the right place at the right time.” Writing for other artists is where he truly found his success. He believes he is one of the main writers in the UK that labels turn to for new artists. He helps launch their careers. Sometimes, he has to explain to the artists he works with that aiming for chart success is not something to be ashamed of. He asks, “Why don’t you want to? Don’t you want 10 million people streaming your music next month?” He emphasizes that they should create something amazing that is also likely to sell well. It is refreshing to hear someone in pop music speak openly about wanting to write hit songs. Scott does not come across as arrogant; he simply understands that he wants to write number one songs and has the talent to do it. Instead of worrying about what others think, he focuses on his goals. He says, “When I go into the studio with someone, we need to aim for the best music of next year. It’s not just about what’s cool. We want to write classic modern pop songs.”

Text: 'Tony Connor is a new kind of celebrity: a big star online, but likely unknown to those who don’t watch online videos of people doing bike stunts. He is a ‘street trials cyclist’ – he jumps from difficult places like roofs or walls to land safely in other challenging spots. These stunts are filmed and shared online. On the day I interview him, we meet in a BMX park on a Saturday morning. The local kids know who he is, and several older people come to greet him, calling him ‘an absolute legend’. After seeing some of his skills, I agree with them. I came with doubts, but I am impressed by his courage, creativity, and willingness to take risks. Before each stunt, he explains what he plans to do, and I sometimes doubt he can succeed. However, when I compliment him afterwards, he seems uninterested and a bit down. Despite his online fame, Tony says he is not comfortable with being a celebrity. ‘I find the social side hard. I understand the importance of connecting with fans, but I prefer to focus on doing things rather than talking about them.’ This is ironic because his fame comes from social media and the small cameras that create much of that content. ‘This technology allows people like me to earn a living,’ he says. ‘Sometimes I feel like everyone is filming themselves or looking at screens, and I don’t fully agree with that.’ Still, he is not complaining. Through his videos, he makes a good living from what would have been just a hobby in the past. After many years of interviewing top athletes, I’ve learned that two key factors turn a passionate child into a top competitor: energy and the ability to overcome emotional disappointment. These traits may be more important than talent and help build the mindset to keep going despite failure. The riskier the sport, the more mental strength is needed. Even in the park, Tony fell a few times on what he considered easy but new challenges. He just got back up and kept trying until he succeeded. Not everyone sees Tony as a hero. Some people think he is reckless and takes too many risks. He says, ‘Those who criticize me may care, but they don’t understand. They probably have never ridden a trials bike and don’t know much about the sport. They don’t see the technical side of what I do and don’t realize I get advice from experts to reduce risks.’ In reality, Tony is careful about the risks he takes. ‘People are different. Some never feel scared, and they probably shouldn’t do these sports; it’s smart to recognize the dangers. The rest of us can be divided into those who can’t overcome fear and those who can. I belong to the group that feels fear but finds a way to move past it. I’m not addicted to risk; I spend hours planning and preparing. Sometimes I need to ride around for a while to get in the right mindset before trying a new stunt. I know I must stay calm just before I jump. If I fully commit, then I’m fine.’

Text: 'Television presenter Helen Skelton has taken on many dangerous challenges for charity, such as running a marathon in the desert and traveling down the Amazon river in a small boat. For her latest challenge, Helen walked on a high wire, which is a long thin piece of metal, 66 meters above the ground, between two towers of an empty power station. There was no safety net; she only had a belt around her waist attached to another wire above. To help her balance and avoid falling, she carried a long stick that weighed eight kilograms. Helen trained with an expert high-wire walker. Even though she had some circus skills, she found that high-wire walking was very different. ‘The training was a shock,’ said Helen. ‘I didn’t know how strong I needed to be. Every day started at 8 am with a run up a steep hill, followed by an hour of exercises, and then another hour practicing on the wire. I also had to learn how to fall onto the wire so that if I slipped, I could keep going. Every time I fell on the wire, it hurt a lot. But it was important to stay positive: if I was nervous and started shaking, the wire would shake too!’ On the day of the challenge, it was windy, and Helen calmed herself by taking deep breaths as she moved step by step along the wire. The 150-meter walk took 15 minutes. ‘That was the scariest thing I’ve done,’ she said afterwards. ‘I’m glad it’s over!’ However, this experience has not stopped Helen from planning her next charity project: to reach the South Pole by ski, kite, and bike.'

In 2006, Jeff Somers started a journey around the world on a penny farthing, an old-style bicycle with one large wheel and one small wheel. He had previously written a book about his travels in Canada using a 50-year-old car. He loved motorsport and worked building racing car engines. To save money, Jeff rode an old bicycle to work and also used it for a holiday in Amsterdam. He said, “That trip opened my eyes. I decided to see the world by bike.” Jeff wanted a unique touring bike and decided to build one himself. He thought a penny farthing would be the most interesting choice, so he visited a museum to learn how they were made. After two attempts in 2001 and 2003, which ended because of a knee injury, he finally began his journey in 2006. He traveled for three years, visiting 23 countries across four continents. The highlight of his trip was reaching Tibet and seeing Mount Everest. He met cyclists who could ride up mountains, but he never regretted using his penny farthing. The further he traveled from home, the more people were amazed by it. His worst experience was having to drink dirty water from a stream, which made him very sick. He spent ten days in a hostel without medicine and had no money for a hospital or to return home. Despite these challenges, Jeff now says, “If I could afford it, I would start traveling again tomorrow on my penny farthing.”

Text: "I work at a university in the US with my team to learn more about water birds, especially the American black duck. We have started using a new tool called a ‘night-vision scope’ that helps us see the ducks in the dark. We are concerned about black ducks because their numbers have decreased significantly, and we are unsure if there is enough food for them on the east coast. We have a lot of information about what they do during the day, but we know very little about their nighttime activities because we did not have the right equipment. This new scope will give us clear images, even on nights without a moon, so we can learn more and make better decisions about protecting their habitat. 

The work is challenging. There are four of us, and we each work six hours a day. We have studied ducks in different places, and I have had to take a boat to some locations and record every duck I see. The weather has been difficult; some nights are warm, but most are rainy. It is very quiet, and I have needed a lot of coffee to stay awake! We have only missed one workday because the snow was too deep for our special vehicles. I enjoy the challenge, especially compared to the summer, when we will spend hours in a laboratory analyzing our results. It will be hard to be indoors, but it is necessary. I wouldn’t change this experience for anything!"

Text: "When I tell people about my job, they often find it hard to believe it exists. But I’m serious! I spend my workdays tasting chocolate! Tasting is a crucial part of ensuring that customers receive perfect, high-quality chocolate from my company. Each week, I get samples, which are small amounts of chocolate from our factory, and I need to check them for taste, texture, and smell. I also taste the raw materials we usually use, like nuts and fruit, to select the best ones for the chocolate. Next to my office, I have a kitchen where I can test and taste the products I create, and I share samples with my colleagues! My kitchen is filled with machines and ingredients to experiment with. It’s great to have a private space to go to during the day. No two days are the same in this job. Sometimes I work in our food lab, and other times I travel abroad to buy raw materials, which can be challenging since I have a young family. However, I enjoy the variety and lack of routine in my job, although I still think the chocolate is the best part! People often ask me if I ever get bored of chocolate. I’ve worked with it for a long time, and I’ve never wanted to stop eating it. In fact, I often go home and eat more in the evening!"

Text: 'Have you ever thought about what it’s like to perform in a circus? Sophia Grayson works at Circus Experience, a center that teaches young people circus skills. She says her course is popular because it includes many skills, such as juggling, throwing and catching objects like balls or even fire, and trapeze, which involves flying through the air in front of an amazed audience. 

In the year-long course, students gradually take more risks in each class, and parents can come to some classes to see their progress. Sophia explains, “For a circus career, performers need to avoid doing the same thing repeatedly – it’s important to keep performances exciting and full of action. If you want to be successful in the circus, you must keep practicing. Another great aspect is the friendships with other performers and the chance to learn from them. Staying fit is also very important – circus artists, like athletes, train every day to stay strong. Training is essential, but the best performers are those who desire success, have creativity, and never stop improving their skills. 

People often think that injuries are common, or that you might only work for a short time each year. However, the real challenge is planning for the future because you can only perform while you’re young, and then you need to think about other options.” The course also includes business planning. Many former students have started businesses around the world and are happy to share their experiences. Sophia warns, though, that it’s not a profession for making a lot of money! “The work usually does not provide a regular salary. It’s also competitive – but a lot of fun!”'

Text: 'You may not know her name or face, but you have probably heard her many times. Mariam Hobson is a professional backing singer, someone who sings in the background to support the main singer. Many people think that backing singers are not good enough to be lead singers, but that is not true – they often have to be even better. People like Mariam are the real stars of the music industry! 

“What I love about my job is that when I enter the recording studio, I never know what I will be asked to sing,” she says. “It could be classical, jazz, hip-hop, or rock. It might even be a funny little song for a radio station or an advertisement. I am often surprised by what producers ask for. Once, I was asked to sing like a fish underwater! But I never complain; I just do my job!”

“Excellent musical skills are very important for my work, as well as the ability to learn quickly. There is often no written music to follow. I will never forget my first experience recording background music for a film. It was very complicated because there were eight of us, each singing a different part, along with an orchestra. I was scared because I knew that if I made a mistake, we would have to record everything again, which nobody likes. Recording sessions are already long enough.”

“One of my favorite jobs is recording for songwriters. Less experienced writers do not always know which musical range is best for a female voice. By listening to me sing their song, they can figure out how to improve it.”'

Text: 'Starting with only basic knowledge of fashion, Julie Deane built a successful business selling ‘satchels’ - traditional bags used by schoolchildren. These satchels are now sold in famous shops and are popular among many celebrities. Before deciding on satchels, Julie considered various business ideas, from cake decorating to party planning, instead of just going with her first thought. Once she made her choice, not everyone supported her. Julie recalls, ‘Many said there was no demand for them – but I was convinced.’ She involved her family from the beginning, working with her mother, who had never had a career but had a natural talent for business. The design of the satchels was inspired by children’s storybooks. Although Julie was not familiar with fashion blogs, they played a key role in her success. Initially, she sold about one satchel a week. To generate interest, Julie sent satchels to fashion writers, hoping they would write about them in their blogs. They did, and interest in her products continued to grow, along with the speed at which her company produced the satchels. Julie now enjoys waiting to see which celebrity is seen with a satchel! While other companies spend money on online ads, she uses the internet community for ideas on new styles, keeping her products fresh and exciting. There was a difficult time when another company copied Julie’s design to sell similar bags, so she now ensures she trusts her production team as much as her own staff. Visitors often comment on the positive atmosphere in her offices – people enjoy working there. There is now a new factory, and while the buildings are important, it is the team that makes it a special place.'

Text: 'When Vicky Harmiston was a child, her parents allowed her and her brother Jamie to choose how they spent their free time. Vicky decided to try many different sports. She was a good swimmer, and her coach believed she could become a champion. However, the swimming club was far from her home, making it hard for her to balance training with her schoolwork. As teenagers, Jamie, who loved cycling, bought a special racing bike and began competing. Vicky found this exciting and decided to try cycling too. She says it was the best choice she ever made. Soon, she was cycling every day and doing very well. The track was close to her school, so attending training sessions after school was easy for her. Vicky had a successful career in track cycling and won several competitions. When she turned 28, she retired from competitive cycling. Vicky explained, ‘For years, I loved winning, but I started to feel tired of it all – when the excitement fades, it loses its meaning. Fortunately, I found a new career.’ Vicky got a job with a charity called CycleZone. ‘We work with young people who have never enjoyed sports,’ she says. ‘The first thing we do is teach them to ride a bike. We want them to learn to believe in themselves and their abilities. CycleZone does important work and helps young people feel part of a community.’ The charity uses celebrities to promote their work. Vicky says, ‘I know some people question whether celebrity support is always good for a charity. They argue that celebrities may be more interested in their own image, which can distract from the charity's real work. But if famous singers and actors can help, I believe they should.’

Text: 'Ana Ronson is a singer-songwriter from Ireland. Even though her parents were not musicians, music was always present in her home. Her grandfather played the guitar and taught Ana and her brother how to play. The first time Ana sang in front of an audience was at school, and she was so nervous that her teacher had to help her off the stage. This teacher suggested that she join the school theatre club to build her confidence. After some time in the club, she happily sang with 50 other students at a concert at the end of the term. A year later, her brother, who was in a band, asked her to write a song for them. She wrote her first song, Falling Stars, in just three days and enjoyed it so much that she signed up for a songwriting course with a professional. Although she was the youngest student, she knew more about music than many others. However, Ana felt that the teacher did not listen to her, which inspired her to write the song Something to Say. She shared this song online, and it became very popular. She was thrilled when people commented that they loved it and found new meanings in her words. Joss Alton, who owns a recording company called Isotope Music, traveled from the other side of Ireland to invite her to join the company. At first, Ana was unsure because she did not know much about Isotope and did not want anyone to control her music. However, Joss assured her that this would not happen, and soon after, she performed at a concert in Dublin organized by Isotope. The tickets sold out quickly, and it was a wonderful evening. Ana prefers to write songs about difficult times rather than happy moments, as she feels she has more to express then. One of her favorite songs is Decision, which is about her brother's temporary stop in singing and how it affected him. While she hopes her fans will enjoy her music, her goal is to write about personal experiences that are important to her.'

Text: 'Last year, I went on an incredible trip – a guided boat tour along the west coast of Canada. It was my brother Harry’s idea. He is a journalist, like me, and wanted to write articles about the trip. He loves boats, although I do not share that interest. However, I had always dreamed of visiting this area since I saw it on TV as a child, especially because it was where our great-grandparents lived before moving to Europe. I kept asking Harry if I could join him until he finally agreed! A few days before we left, there were storms in the area we were going to. Luckily, the weather forecast for our trip was calm seas. I was busy at work and didn’t have much time to prepare, but Harry promised he would handle everything, so I stopped worrying. 

After arriving in Canada, we joined the group, packed our supplies into small boats, and set off. The guide mentioned that very few people live along that coast, and indeed, the only other living creatures we saw that first morning were dolphins and birds. We could see islands in the distance, but the early-morning fog made it hard to see far, so I focused on the beautiful patterns our boat made in the water. We often stopped for hours to explore the rock pools on the beaches. They were full of colorful fish, many of which I didn’t recognize. It was wonderful to forget about how fast or slow the day was passing. We never forgot lunch or dinner, which we all cooked together over campfires. When we finally fell asleep on the boats each evening, even though the beds were hard, it felt like a stress-free life! When it was time to leave, I felt sad. How could I return to normal life? But I knew if I stayed, I would miss my family and friends. I was also excited to tell everyone at home about our adventures!'

Text: "My dad was a professional basketball player in Germany, just like his father before him. I watched many of his games when I was a child. You might think that seeing so many matches would make me love the sport, but it actually did the opposite. I enjoyed telling my friends how good my dad was, especially when he won, but I often took a book to read instead of watching the games. 

When I started secondary school, I was still two years away from being a teenager, but I was already two meters tall. Seeing my height, my sports teacher asked if I wanted to train with the basketball team. I liked the training session, but I thought I needed to improve my skills before playing in a real match. However, the teacher believed in me more than I believed in myself. After some time, I agreed, and a few weeks later, I found myself playing against another school’s team. My parents watching made me more nervous, but it turned out fine!

For the next four years, I practiced every day and did very well, even joining an adult team before moving to a special sports academy in the USA when I was fifteen. The coach there trains Olympic basketball players, and it was amazing to work with him. However, I didn’t enjoy living far from my parents at first. At home, I hadn’t spent much time with friends because of all the training, so that part wasn’t a big change for me. Eventually, I got used to my new life, and my English improved quickly too! I became a professional player at eighteen, three years after arriving in the USA. I had been taller than most players in the professional league since I was fifteen, but I needed to gain weight to match my height. My coach knew a team that would take me while I was still in college, so I joined them and have never regretted it."

Text: "Seven years ago, I was studying Tourism at college and needed a part-time job because my course was expensive. After thinking about different options, I trained to be a weekend tour guide in my home city, Chicago, USA. I took visitors around the city and was surprised by how much I enjoyed giving tours. I saw the city I had lived in my whole life from the perspective of tourists, and it felt like a new experience each time! After finishing my studies, I decided to become a full-time tour guide. I thought it would be easy, but when I researched what I needed to do, I learned that to get a license as a full-time tour guide, I had to know much more than I had learned so far. All Chicago guides must answer many questions about the city, including local architecture, history, and public transport rules. After several challenging but interesting months, I earned my tour guide qualification and registered as an independent tour guide. 

Tour guiding is not just about knowing historical facts or keeping track of your group in crowds. There are many other important skills. You need to be entertaining and tell interesting stories, and most importantly, you must be able to adapt to changing situations. For example, if a place you thought was open is actually closed when you arrive, or if the route changes. Tourists do not want to hear about problems or that they are missing something; they just want to enjoy a well-organized tour. I must ensure visitors are happy with my tours, or they might leave a negative review online. Like most tour guides, I understand that these reviews are very important because good reviews attract more customers. That is why making tours enjoyable and stress-free is essential. For me, the enthusiasm and energy I put into my job mean that my reviews are usually very good, and my tours are often recommended to other visitors coming to Chicago."

Text: 'My name is Ella, and I am 22 years old. Last year, I went to Thailand for two weeks with my sister, Josie. Even though she is five years younger than me, we have a good relationship. We went to volunteer at an elephant sanctuary, which is a place where people care for sick and rescued elephants. At first, I was unsure if we would connect with the other volunteers because they were all older than us. We were also nervous since it was our first time doing something like this. However, we ended up having a great experience. 

One of our main tasks at the sanctuary was to collect food for the elephants. Elephants eat a lot of grass and banana plants, so this took most of our day. Josie found it very hard work, but seeing the elephants enjoy their meals made it worthwhile for me. We also helped wash the elephants in the river with big brushes and soap. I found this very enjoyable, even though I got wetter than the elephants! 

The part of the day I looked forward to the most was the evening. By moonlight, we led the elephants into the forest where they spent the night. All the volunteers stayed in the same house. Josie and I shared a small bedroom because she didn’t want to be alone. It was hot and humid, especially at night, but we expected that. The meals were delicious and did not include meat, which we both do not like. After dinner, all the volunteers and staff spent the evenings talking and playing games. 

Now that we are back in the UK, Josie does not often talk about Thailand. But if someone asks her if she enjoyed her time at the sanctuary, she says she loved it. However, I think she might be a little upset with herself for not fully enjoying her time there because she missed her friends too much. But when she reflects on the experience, she realizes how lucky she was to go. Maybe she will return one day – I definitely will!'

Text: "My name is Gina D’Costa, and I own a flower shop in the UK. We sell flowers not just for personal gifts or home decoration; we have many types of customers. Hotels and offices often use flowers in their reception areas, and we sometimes provide flowers for businesses' advertising photos. Once, I even decorated a castle for a wedding, which was a lot of work, but I felt very proud of what we accomplished. 

My day begins at 4 a.m. when I go to the market to buy fresh flowers. Most people are still asleep at that time, and my friends think I’m a bit crazy, but I love what I do. It can be quite cold and dark, but I don’t let that bother me. The flower market is amazing, with flowers from all over the world. The sights and smells make it hard to choose. If I were picking for myself, I would probably choose only pink flowers, as that is my favorite color. However, I have to remember that my preferences may not match what customers want. 

Sometimes, it’s difficult to find the flowers customers want because not all flowers are available all year round. I don’t enjoy negotiating prices with the flower sellers, but it is part of the job. Flowers can be expensive, so I try to get the best price I can. 

Back at the shop, we review customer orders and arrange the flowers I bought into vases. Then, we create flower bunches and calculate the costs of the orders. Customers are often surprised by the prices, and I sometimes have to ask them to reconsider their choices. Some people might think this is too much work, but I enjoy figuring out how to create beautiful arrangements within a budget. That’s what selling is about, and I wouldn’t want to do anything else!"

Text: "My city has a modern cinema that shows the latest films and many children's movies on weekends. It is close to my home, but a year ago, I realized I wanted something more – the chance to discuss a film in detail with others after watching it. So, I started a film club with two friends! We decided not to rent a cinema for our screenings. Instead, we choose a different location in the city each month. For example, we used an old factory to show a film set in Antarctica. It was very cold, which created a great atmosphere for the film, and it was fantastic! Some places we use are free because the owners sell snacks during the film, allowing us to keep our prices low. We are happy to cover our costs without making a profit. Each time we show a film, it gets easier, especially now that we have our own reliable equipment. We can track ticket sales online, so we no longer worry about empty seats! There is always a lot to do, but when people of all ages tell us how much they enjoyed the experience, it feels wonderful. Our website has been very helpful, and we are now connected with other film clubs across the country. We have visited them to see how they operate, but it is always nice to return to our own club! We also started a blog because we know most people look online for film information instead of reading local reviews. We have tried putting up posters in cafés, but nothing is as effective as word of mouth – people telling their friends about us. The audience loves the special activities we organize with each film; last month, we had a movie quiz that everyone enjoyed."

Text: "Taking photographs was always my favorite activity as a child. When I was 15, I wanted to take my hobby to the next level, so I decided to start a personal project: I would take one photograph every day for a whole year. Many other young photographers had done this before, but it seemed like a great idea to me, so I began. After a few weeks, I decided to share these photos on a website for young photographers because I wanted to create a photo diary and show others my work. I was surprised to find that many people liked my perspective and style. I enjoyed photographing a variety of subjects. Then someone suggested that if my photos had a common theme, my project would be even better, and I agreed. I started focusing more on nature scenes, especially birds and the sky. Many of my photos were black and white, which was different from what most young photographers were doing, as they were taking color photos. Because of this, I sometimes doubted my project and almost gave up. In the end, I trusted my feelings and became more confident in my style and choices. One day, I showed my project to my art teacher. She told me about a national photography competition for my age group, so I entered some of my photos just for fun. I will never forget the moment when the judges told me I had won first prize; I was so happy because my project meant a lot to me. It was the first time I realized that my photography might be good, and that I could work as a professional photographer. Now, I have my own photography studio, and I have never regretted my career choice."

Text: 'I joined the National Youth Challenge (NYC) last year because I wanted to try new activities like camping, sailing, and public speaking. In the NYC, you can participate in various activities that help you grow and learn. There are different levels, from beginner to advanced, led by adult volunteers called ‘leaders’. When you finish each level, you receive a certificate. 

When I first joined, my leader suggested that I help organize activities at a local children’s club for two hours a week. I was unsure about this because I had joined that same club when I was eight and found it hard to make friends. I was shy, and the other children already had their own groups, so I stopped going after a few weeks. However, I decided to take on the challenge because I wanted my first NYC certificate. 

Soon, I found myself wanting to spend all my free time at the children’s club. It became much more important to me than just getting the certificate. After I completed the challenge, the NYC leader allowed me to continue volunteering at the club because I had formed good relationships with the children. Now, I spend about four hours a week there, and I always look forward to it. 

Because of what I learned at the children’s club, I have decided that after I finish school in three years, I want to go to college to become a qualified youth worker, someone who works with children. I had never thought about my future job or youth work before starting at the club. This experience has been my favorite part of the NYC, and I have improved my communication skills while helping others. I now have several NYC certificates, including one for camping!'

Text: 'I was born in Denver, USA, and I started snowboarding when I was eight years old. My dad took me to a mountain resort about two hours from Denver. The hill looked very steep, so my dad had to convince me to try snowboarding. I was too young to ask him if I could start, but he loved the sport and wanted me to enjoy it too. He made it look easy, and eventually, I did well. Soon, I developed a passion for snowboarding and improved my skills. I began competing when I was ten. Some people enter many competitions and get bored, but my love for participating and winning has grown as I’ve aged, which motivates me to work harder. I like not having a strict plan, and sometimes this works out well, like when I became the first female to score a perfect 100 at a local competition. I wasn’t sure I would try the jumps that earned me that score until I actually started. That achievement boosted my confidence in my abilities. In the summer, I focus on training and studying when there’s no snow. I train every day, but it’s nice not to follow a strict diet like I do in winter. I also spend a lot of time with my friends during this time. It helps me cope with not being able to do what I love and what I’m good at. I need to think about my future. Snowboarding is a big part of my life, but I also believe it’s important to have another option in case I don’t become a professional snowboarder or if I get injured. I’m considering whether becoming a doctor is possible if my active life allows time for college. I can’t imagine getting tired of snowboarding, but I know I can’t do it forever.'

Text: 'When I was fifteen, I wanted everything my friends had, and I never thought about the future. For example, I didn’t know what I wanted to do after school. One day, my best friend got a new phone for her birthday, and I thought I should have one too. My parents said I could only have it if I paid for it myself, so I decided to work part-time and save money. I am grateful to my parents for making me do that – it taught me an important lesson. I worked every Saturday in a café, but I didn’t enjoy it much, so my parents suggested I start my own small business. I had seen my mum making necklaces, so I asked if I could try that. I never thought it would be so easy, as it looked complicated when I watched Mum. My friends thought it sounded boring, but I was excited about it. Mum showed me that I could create something nice at home with simple tools and materials. I sold my first pieces of jewellery to my friends and family as soon as I finished making them. They said they loved them, but I thought they were just being nice. Even though I was happy they bought them, I still needed to be sure they looked good enough for others to buy. The only way to find out was to rent a market stall with my mum. There are many tourists where I live, and they bought a lot of my items to take home. Soon, we started getting calls from all over the country from people wanting to buy more. They thought we were a big company with many workers, but we were just two people at a market stall! That was when I realized it could work, and it was time to take the next step – creating a website. Since then, I’ve made thousands of pounds from my business, mostly online, but we still have our stall too. It has been a lot of fun so far.'

Text: 'When Janine Stuart was just 13 years old, she wrote a novel called Being Amelia, which became a bestseller. Being Amelia is partly inspired by Janine’s own life. In an interview about her book, Janine said, “Because of my father’s job, my family moved around the country a lot, so I’ve learned to make new friends easily. I know what it’s like to be the only new student in a class, and that helped me write about how the main character, Amelia, adjusts to a new school. Some of the funniest parts of the book are about Amelia’s home life, especially her relationship with her older brother. Since I’m my parents’ only child, I had to use my imagination to describe that.” 

Janine started her novel one summer when she was bored at home. Her mother had always wanted to be a published author, and her teachers encouraged her to write, so it felt natural for Janine to spend her time this way. The year before, she entered a short story competition on a young writers’ website and won first prize. That’s why, when Janine finished Being Amelia and sent it to a publishing company, they were eager to read it. They loved it, and a year later, Janine’s novel was available in bookstores. 

One review of Being Amelia notes that, despite the book having pictures of happy teenagers on the cover, the characters face real challenges, which makes them believable. The reviewer mentions that even though Janine is still very young and Being Amelia isn’t a long novel, she has shown that she is a better writer than many other bestselling authors. Janine is still adjusting to being a famous writer: “At first, I would hide when people recognized me in the street, but now it’s fine. I want to give advice to other young writers, but they need to find what works for them. For me, I know that if I spend time with my friends, I’ll soon have something interesting to write about!”'

Text: "My name is Tom, and I am fifteen years old. Three years ago, my family and I moved to a castle on a small island. This happened because my father was invited to manage the castle. He works for a group that takes care of historical buildings and keeps them open for visitors. He was happy about this opportunity, but it took some time for the rest of us to agree that he should accept the job. We were worried about what life on the island would be like. We knew the castle might not be as comfortable as our warm home across the water, and there was no school nearby. However, once we moved, we quickly adapted to island life. The castle is not very beautiful, but our apartment there is comfortable. In summer, the island is lively with many visitors, and there are often beach parties. In winter, we mostly see the other families who live on the island, but there are not many teenagers among them, which I had hoped for. The adults help each other and work together on repairs around the island, which can be hard work. 

The biggest change for me was taking a boat every day to my old school. I looked forward to going on stormy days when there are big waves, but the ferries do not run then! I also learned that if I miss the bus to the harbor after school, I will miss the last ferry home, which is stressful. So, when my friends come to visit, I always tell them to hurry! But we often enjoy amazing views, especially when the sun sets over the sea. Some days, it is so foggy that you cannot see anything, but then, within hours, it can be bright and sunny again. This still feels incredible, even after living here for a while. Of course, we do experience terrible storms, and I sometimes wonder if the castle is strong enough to withstand them. But then I remind myself that it has been here for centuries and is still standing!"

Text: 'I live in a house in the beautiful countryside of Scotland. I have always loved nature and wild animals, and six years ago, I started a new hobby – birdwatching! I went to the mountains in northern Scotland with my family, where we saw many birds in their natural habitat. I spent hours watching them with my parents, who taught me how to identify different species and find the best spots to see them. It was amazing, and after returning home, I joined a local birdwatchers’ club for young people. My goal is to see 200 different bird species, and I am close to achieving that. During family holidays abroad, I have had the chance to see birds from other countries as well. We always look for places with group birdwatching activities so I can add new birds to my list! I have been to Egypt, and last summer we went to South America, where I thought I would see my 200th species. I was not too disappointed when it didn’t happen, as I have learned that patience is important in this hobby. I posted a video online about this challenge, and many teenagers found it interesting and commented positively. When my teachers saw it, they asked me to give a presentation about birdwatching at school. I felt nervous just before I walked onto the stage, but I knew I would remember what to say and had some notes to help me. I only relaxed when it was over, and the teachers said I had prepared well and they enjoyed it. I might even do another presentation next year! I am lucky to live in the countryside. I understand why many teenagers in cities might not consider becoming birdwatchers, but there are many birds to see, especially in areas with lots of green spaces. I also believe that birdwatching clubs should work to attract more young people to this hobby. Everyone should connect with nature, no matter their age, and it doesn’t have to be expensive.'

Text: "I began playing football when I was 7 years old. I would hurry home from school to play with other kids. I loved it, and soon I became a decent player. My family knew I often got excited about new hobbies and then lost interest, so they probably thought I would do the same with football. But that never happened. I even started dreaming of playing football professionally when I grew up. The chance came sooner than I expected. I played in local tournaments, and one referee saw that I was a talented player. He asked the manager of a professional women’s club to watch me. After that, she invited me to join her club. I was surprised at first because I didn’t know young girls could join women’s clubs. But the manager was impressed, and I started regular training with a big club when I was just 13. After that, I improved a lot. Still, some people doubted I would ever be a star player, which made me a little sad. But my coach encouraged me to be myself and believe in myself. He even let me play in one of the club’s championship matches earlier than I expected! I ran harder than ever because I didn’t want to let the other players down. By chance, I scored the winning goal. Even with the large crowd, I could hear my coach cheering for me, and after the match, my team carried me around the pitch. It was amazing! Since then, I’ve scored many more winning goals! Next month, my coach and I are organizing a football tournament in my area. The goal is to get teenagers interested in football and give them a chance to meet other players from my club. It will show them what a professional environment is like and encourage them to believe they could play for a top team if they work hard. My advice to them will be the same as my coach’s advice to me – there will be good times, but also some bad times. I’ve had very few bad times, though – so I’ve been lucky!"

Text: 'In recent years, there has been an interesting trend in further and higher education in the UK and around the world. This trend encourages new students to get involved in research as early as possible in their studies. This idea shows that research is not just for famous scholars at old universities or scientists making new discoveries, but is also a natural way to build knowledge and skills. Research skills will be helpful not only in your studies but also in your future jobs, as they help you think about the world and how to approach your work.

As a student, you contribute to knowledge. You do not just learn and repeat information; you create it. Creating knowledge involves asking questions instead of accepting things as they are. You might wonder: Why? How? When? What does this mean? What if things were different? How does it work in this situation? What should we think about the facts, opinions, or beliefs we encounter? Why is this important? These questions are at the heart of what we call research.

Research can be seen as a range of activities. On one end, there is complex, groundbreaking research done by highly trained experts, which leads to significant changes and new knowledge. However, research can also start from simple inquiries that involve careful work, thoughtful questions about issues, and practical suggestions.

Most students have always been researchers in some way. You have likely done some research for school projects or answered questions at work since you started. You have asked questions that led you to investigate topics, whether it was about where to go on holiday, how to grow plants, fix things at home, train your dog, find the right music system, or shop online.

In college and higher education, it is expected that you will have a curious mind, identify problems and questions, critically explore and evaluate information, and create your own responses and knowledge to contribute to discussions. Some students may find this challenging because, in some cultures, knowledge is seen as fixed, and learning comes from listening to teachers and texts. It may feel disrespectful to question established knowledge and authority, and you might think you should be told what is important to learn.

However, in higher education in the UK, US, much of Europe, and Australasia, questioning established knowledge and authorities is encouraged. This process of inquiry and knowledge creation can seem overwhelming. Critical thinking is especially important in research. The research done by others is valuable for students, academics, and professionals, but we must not just repeat what we read as if it is true. We need to engage with it, think critically, test it, and determine if the information is logical and supported by evidence. We should avoid blindly accepting facts and information from our readings or conversations.'

Text: 'Cities have always been centers of intellectual activity, from the coffee houses of 18th-century London, where people discussed science and politics, to the cafés of modern Paris, where artist Pablo Picasso talked about art. However, living in a city is not easy. The same London cafés that encouraged discussion also helped spread diseases like cholera; Picasso eventually moved to the countryside. While modern cities can be creative places, they can also feel unnatural and overwhelming. Scientists are now studying how city life affects our brains, and the findings are concerning. It has long been known that city life is tiring, but new research shows that living in cities can actually reduce our ability to think clearly. One major reason for this is the lack of nature, which is surprisingly good for our brains. Studies have shown that hospital patients recover faster when they can see trees from their windows. Even small views of nature can help our brains because they provide a break from the busy city life. This research comes at a time when more people than ever live in cities. Instead of living in open spaces, we are packed into concrete environments, surrounded by many strangers. Recent studies show that these unnatural surroundings can significantly affect our mental and physical health and change how we think. Think about everything your brain has to manage when walking down a busy street: distracted people, dangerous crossings that require attention to traffic, and the confusing layout of the city. These small mental tasks can leave us feeling exhausted because they take a lot of mental energy. Cities are filled with so many distractions that we constantly have to shift our focus. This process of deciding what to pay attention to and what to ignore uses a lot of our brain's energy. In contrast, natural environments do not require as much mental effort. This idea is called attention restoration theory, developed by psychologist Stephen Kaplan. It has been known for a long time that our ability to focus is limited – if we concentrate hard in the morning, it becomes harder to focus in the afternoon. Kaplan suggested that being in nature could help restore our attention. Natural settings have many things that naturally attract our attention but do not cause negative feelings, unlike loud noises like police sirens. In nature, our mental focus can relax and recharge. Long before scientists studied this, philosophers and landscape architects warned about the negative effects of city life and sought ways to include nature in urban areas. Urban parks, like Central Park in New York, provide a break from city life. A well-designed park can enhance brain function in just a few minutes. While people have looked for various ways to boost brain performance, from energy drinks to office redesigns, it seems that simply taking a walk in nature is one of the most effective methods. Given the many mental challenges caused by city life, one might wonder: Why do cities keep growing? And why do they remain important centers of intellectual activity, even in the digital age? Recent research from the Santa Fe Institute shows that the same urban features that can lead to problems with attention and memory – like crowded streets and close proximity to others – are also linked to innovation. Scientists believe that the ‘concentration of social interactions’ is a key factor in urban creativity. Just as the crowded environment of 18th-century London led to new ideas, the busy atmosphere of 21st-century Cambridge, Massachusetts, supports its role as a hub of technology and creativity. Conversely, less crowded urban areas may produce less innovation over time. The challenge, then, is to find ways to reduce the negative effects of city life while keeping its unique advantages. Because there will always be moments when someone feels: ‘I’m tired of nature; take me to the city!’'

**Simplified Text:**

Where should we look for the mind? This question may seem strange because we usually think that thinking happens inside our heads. Today, we have advanced brain imaging techniques that support this idea. However, I believe there is no strong reason to limit the study of the mind to just the brain or the body. There is a lot of evidence, from ancient times to now, showing that objects, as well as brain cells, play a role in how we think. 

From an archaeological perspective, it is clear that tools, jewelry, carvings, clay tokens, and writing systems have actively contributed to human development and the formation of the mind. Therefore, I propose that what exists outside our heads may also be part of our minds. It is understandable why we often connect the mind with the brain. Most of what we know about the mind comes from studying people in isolation from their surroundings. This is practical for neuroscientists, especially when using brain scanners. However, this approach often overlooks the fact that much of our thinking happens outside our heads. 

I do not want to deny the importance of the brain in thinking, but I want to emphasize that the mind is more than just the brain. It is more useful to consider the idea that human intelligence extends beyond our bodies into culture and the material world. This is where my new theory, called Material Engagement Theory (MET), comes in. MET explores how objects can become extensions of our thinking or be integrated into our bodies. For example, when we create numbers and symbols from clay or use a stone to make a tool, we are engaging with materials in a cognitive way. 

MET also looks at how these interactions have changed since ancient times and what these changes mean for our thinking. This approach provides new insights into what minds are and how they are shaped by the things around us. For instance, consider a blind person using a stick. Where does this person’s self begin? The connection between the blind person and the stick helps us understand that minds and objects can be seen as connected. It also illustrates the flexibility of the human mind: by using the stick, the blind person can turn touch into a form of sight, and the stick itself plays an important role. 

The stick shows us that human intelligence can adapt and change significantly by incorporating new technologies. I view the human mind as an ongoing project that is always evolving. It is important to remember that, regardless of what form the “stick” has taken throughout history—whether it is a simple stone tool or a modern smartphone—its main purpose is to connect us to the world. 

Through the “stick,” humans explore, learn, and understand their environment, while also finding new paths forward. This is different from how monkeys use sticks to get food. For humans, “sticks” are tools for satisfying our curiosity. This unique ability to engage with material culture explains why humans create more than any other species, and how these creations shape our minds. I call this metaplasticity—our minds are flexible and change as we interact with the material world. I want to emphasize the importance of material objects in understanding the mind. MET provides a new perspective on how various forms of material culture, from ancient tools to modern devices, have influenced who we are and how we think. While the idea of technology changing our minds may sound futuristic, it is important to realize that humans have been using such technology since our early evolution.

Text: 'Few inventions have changed the course of civilization as much as photography. This is especially true in the United States, where photography quickly became part of American culture at all levels – from practical and scientific uses to industrial and aesthetic purposes, as well as a new world of entertainment that emerged with the camera. Historians argue that photography is one of the greatest contributions of the United States to the visual arts. No other art form has had such a significant impact from the US. This claim reflects the idea that photography has become central to American intellectual and artistic discussions, and to fully appreciate its impact, we must look at its beginnings in the mid-19th century. 

Why was this new art form so appealing? First, photography was a mechanical process that matched a growing interest in technology, part of a national mindset that accepted change as normal. Just as steam power, railroads, and electricity made the world smaller by improving communication and travel, photography brought the wonders of the world into homes with an immediacy that was astonishing. 

Second, the camera became the preferred tool for representing the self, allowing individuals to create images for public viewing in a society where personal and national identities were constantly being formed and reformed. Third, the camera has been very important for creating and preserving family memories, even if these memories are somewhat idealized. Finally, the realism of photographs aligned with a trend towards realism in the work of American artists, focusing on everyday life. 

Every photograph draws attention to something specific, showing what the photographer wants us to see. The fact that a photograph is made by a machine, rather than drawn by hand, gives it a unique quality: photographs are records of events, people, and things; they are at least records of what was in front of the camera, which gives them a sense of objectivity. However, because each photograph is taken by a specific person, it also carries a subjective point of view. 

We may look at a photograph and think we understand its meaning, especially if we recognize the subject. This has led to photography being called a ‘universal language’ since its inception. But the meaning of photographs is more complex. Few things in front of us – whether a person, object, or event – convey their own meaning; and no image is presented to us without some context that shapes our understanding of it, such as a caption in a newspaper or its placement in a gallery. 

To understand a photograph historically, we need to consider its purpose and role within a specific cultural context: Why did the photographer take the image? How did people first view it? Additionally, the same image might be seen in different places and times, leading to different meanings. 

While the importance of the camera to artists was not widely recognized for a long time, it is now clear to contemporary artists. For several decades, starting with U.S. artist Andy Warhol’s use of photographs in his paintings and silk screens, artists have been integrating photographs into their work in various ways. In summary, photographic vision has become an essential part of painting in the history of art, rather than being seen as separate from it.'

In 1890, William James, an American philosopher and physician, defined psychology as the "science of mental life." This definition is still relevant today. We all have a mental life, which gives us some understanding of what this means. Although we can study this concept in animals like rats and monkeys, it remains somewhat difficult to grasp. James focused on human psychology, which he believed included basic elements: thoughts, feelings, a physical world that exists in time and space, and a way of knowing about these elements. Our knowledge is mostly personal and comes from our own thoughts, feelings, and experiences, which may or may not be influenced by scientific facts. 

This personal knowledge can lead us to make judgments about psychological issues based on our own experiences. We often act as amateur psychologists when we share opinions on complex psychological topics, such as whether brainwashing works or why people behave in certain ways, like feeling insulted or unhappy. Problems can arise when two people understand things differently. Formal psychology aims to provide methods to determine which explanations are most likely correct in a given situation. Psychologists help us differentiate between subjective thoughts, which can be biased, and objective facts.

Psychology, as defined by William James, is about the mind or brain. While psychologists study the brain, they do not yet fully understand how it works in relation to our hopes, fears, and behaviors during various experiences, such as giving birth or watching a football match. It is often not possible to study the brain directly, so psychologists learn more by observing behavior and forming hypotheses about what happens inside us.

A challenge in psychology is that scientific facts should be objective and verifiable, but the mind's workings are not directly observable like a machine's. We can only perceive them indirectly through behavior. Studying psychology is similar to solving a crossword puzzle; it requires evaluating and interpreting clues. These clues must come from careful observation, accurate measurement, and logical analysis that can be publicly examined. 

Psychology often involves complex interactions, and understanding them requires advanced techniques and theories. Like any other science, psychology aims to describe, understand, predict, and learn how to control or change the processes it studies. Achieving these goals helps us understand our experiences and apply findings to real-life situations. Psychological research has been beneficial in various fields, such as improving teaching methods, designing safer machines, and helping people express their feelings better.

Although psychological questions have been discussed for centuries, scientific investigation of these questions has only occurred in the last 150 years. Early psychologists used introspection, or self-reflection, to find answers. They aimed to identify mental structures, which is still important today, but introspection has clear limitations. As Sir Francis Galton noted, it only allows us to see a small part of the mind's automatic processes. William James compared trying to understand the mind through introspection to "turning up the gas quickly enough to see how the darkness looks." Therefore, modern psychologists prefer to base their theories on careful observations of behavior rather than on personal reflections.

Text: 'In a storehouse in a typical business park in Michigan, USA, lies a collection of failed consumer products – a contrast to the positive, success-driven culture of modern marketing. Here, you can find items like A Touch of Yogurt shampoo and Breakfast Cola, both of which were not popular. This collection, now owned by a company called GfK, is informally known as the Museum of Failed Products. It showcases products that were taken off the market because few people wanted to buy them. The museum’s owner, Carol Sherry, believes that each product tells a sad story about the designers, marketers, and salespeople involved. 

What is most surprising about the museum is that it exists as a profitable business. You might think that any serious manufacturer would keep a collection of their own failed products. However, the executives who visit the museum show how rare this is. They seem to avoid thinking about their failures and often do not keep samples of their unsuccessful products. The museum itself was an unexpected success. Its creator, Robert McMath, originally wanted to create a ‘reference library’ of consumer products, not just failed ones. Starting in the 1960s, he began buying samples of every new item he could find. What he did not realize was that most products fail. By collecting new products without discrimination, McMath ended up with mostly unsuccessful items.

Today’s culture of optimism may explain why these failed products made it to the museum. Each product likely went through meetings where no one recognized it would fail. Even if they did, marketers might invest more money into a failing product to try to save face. Little effort is usually made to understand why the products failed; everyone involved may have agreed, perhaps unknowingly, to never discuss it again. 

This focus on optimism is especially common in the growing ‘self-help’ industry. A popular idea here is ‘positive visualization’: if you imagine things going well, they are more likely to happen – or so the belief goes. Research by neuroscientist Tali Sharot suggests that a healthy mind may be inclined to see the chances of success as better than they actually are. Her studies indicate that well-adjusted people often have a less accurate and overly optimistic view of their ability to influence outcomes compared to those who are depressed.

But how effective are these ‘positive fantasies about the future’? This is the question that psychologist Gabriele Oettingen and her team have been exploring. Their findings are surprising: spending time imagining how well things could go often reduces people’s motivation to reach their goals. For instance, groups of people who were encouraged to think about having a very successful week at work ended up achieving less.

Psychologist Carol Dweck suggests that our experiences with failure are shaped by our beliefs about ability. Dweck explains that people with a ‘fixed mindset’ believe ability is something you are born with, while those with a ‘growth mindset’ think it develops through effort and challenges. People with a fixed mindset find failure particularly distressing, seeing it as proof that they did not measure up. A common example is a sports star who thinks of himself as a ‘natural’ but fails to practice enough to reach his potential. In contrast, those with a growth mindset view failure as a sign that they are pushing their limits. Dweck compares this to weight training: muscles grow by being pushed to their limits, where they tear and heal, becoming stronger. The deeper message is that having a growth mindset is a more positive way to approach life, regardless of whether it leads to success.'

Text: 'Everyone knows that sports teams have an advantage when they play at home. But why is that? Many of us think we understand, but professional sports are changing quickly, and what we once accepted is now being questioned. Two main factors are challenging the idea of home advantage: science and money. Sports scientists want to discover what helps players perform their best, leading to many theories about home advantage. At the same time, investors want to know why home advantage is still important. If players are paid well, shouldn’t they feel comfortable playing anywhere?

What does this mean for fans? Would it matter if Manchester United played some home games in the Far East to reach their fans there? It would matter to British fans, who believe their team needs their support and loyalty. This may lead them to confuse cause and effect. People often think that events are best explained by the order they remember them, rather than how they actually happened. When a team advances, home fans cheer loudly, and sometimes this leads to a goal, causing the crowd to erupt. Fans tend to remember the times they cheered and a goal was scored, forgetting the many times their cheers did not lead to success.

However, there is one common belief among fans that scientific evidence supports. Home fans not only cheer for their team but also direct a lot of their noise at the referee. In a well-known experiment, referees watched a match with crowd noise and another group watched in silence. The referees who heard the crowd were less likely to call fouls against the home team than those who watched silently. Interestingly, the crowd noise did not make them more likely to call fouls against the away team. The researchers concluded that referees try to avoid extra stress from making calls against the home team. They do not simply follow the crowd; they aim to avoid the crowd's anger.

Recent studies on home advantage have looked at long-term trends. They show that home advantage has decreased in all major sports, but not as much as expected. For example, in the early years of the Football League in the 1890s in England, home teams won about 70% of the points, compared to 60% today. One reason for this may be travel, which used to be difficult; now, football players travel in great comfort, and if their hotel is not good enough, someone from the club will find them a better one. Local conditions used to vary greatly, but now top stadiums are increasingly similar in their efficiency.

Despite these explanations, none fully explains the data. These changes—pampered players, modern support staff, and similar stadiums—have all happened relatively recently. The mystery remains why home advantage varies by sport. Basketball has the greatest home advantage, followed by football, while baseball has the least. One reason might be that home advantage is more about teamwork, and baseball focuses more on individual matchups between batter and pitcher. Team sports require coordination among teammates. In basketball, success depends on all players working together, which builds confidence in their ability to connect on the court. This confidence seems to grow from the familiarity of playing at home, regardless of playing conditions.

Another possibility relates to a more aggressive side of sports. Researchers found that players’ testosterone levels were normal before training and away games but increased by up to 67% before home games. This territorial feeling may connect to a basic instinct to defend their home ground, as seen in the recent Rugby World Cup. In two notable games, underdog teams won at home against stronger opponents, showing determination and a refusal to be intimidated—clear signs of home advantage. As one referee put it, ‘It’s the law of the jungle out there.’"

Text: "‘The more I practice, the luckier I get,’ said golfer Gary Player about fifty years ago. This saying is famous among dedicated athletes and their coaches. The reason is clear. First, there is debate about who originally said it, with many golfers from that time being suggested. Second, the meaning is not straightforward. Player did not mean 'lucky' in a literal sense; he was being ironic. His true message was: ‘The more I practice, the better I get.’ But there is a limit to this idea. The question of where that limit is, or if it even exists, relates to the nature-nurture debate – whether talent is something we are born with or something we develop through practice. However, it is misleading to call it a debate, as it suggests a fair balance. In reality, the evidence strongly favors nurture. The idea that practice is more important than natural talent in sports, music, business, and other areas comes from psychologist Anders Ericsson. He is known for the theory that anyone can become an expert with 10,000 hours of practice. This theory has inspired many popular books, including Malcolm Gladwell’s Outliers, Talent Is Overrated, and Bounce: The Myth of Talent and the Power of Practice. These books generally agree that practice is the most important factor, concluding that ‘10,000 hours is both necessary and sufficient to make anyone an expert in anything.’ However, as Epstein discusses in his engaging book, this is often not the case. He points out a major flaw in much research on excellence: it usually focuses only on successful individuals. ‘Science is much better at looking at an elite athlete and suggesting why that person is succeeding after the fact.’ Are there other ways to understand why some people have certain abilities while others do not? Epstein travels the world, from Kenya to Sweden, and from the Caribbean to the Arctic, to find answers. In Alaska, he discovers that the key to success in the toughest sled dog race may be the dogs’ drive and desire, suggesting a link between genetics and traits we think are voluntary. Some interpretations of the 10,000-hours rule assume that commitment and determination are choices. But what if, as the huskies’ case suggests, a person’s drive has a genetic basis? Such examples highlight the complexity of the topic. Epstein differentiates between hardware (nature) and software (nurture), agreeing that elite athletes need both. He does not deny the importance of training or environment, suggesting that if Usain Bolt had grown up in the US, he might have been a good basketball player instead of the fastest man in history. However, he also examines cases where genetics play a crucial role. He raises important questions about race and gender, asking: ‘If only practice hours matter, why do we separate men and women in sports?’ Sometimes, the best questions are the most obvious."

Text: 'A recent international report shows that many children in rich, developed countries feel lonely and unhappy. Jay Griffiths asks a simple question: why are today’s children so unhappy? In her new book, Kith, Griffiths explains that these children spend too much time indoors, stuck in front of screens, whether watching TV or using computers, and have lost touch with nature – the woods, mountains, rivers, and streams. She believes this is the main issue. This idea connects with other discussions about childhood today. A follow-up study interviewed some children to understand their feelings better. The study found that many children do not wish for more technology; instead, they would be happier if they could go outside more. Many adults over 40 often talk fondly about their own childhoods, remembering how they spent long summer days exploring, swimming, or building forts. They believe this was much better and healthier than the protected lives of today’s children. However, they often forget that they are the ones who created this protective environment for their kids, avoiding risks like building forts in old sheds. 

Griffiths’ book contains strong arguments. She discusses the fear parents have about dangers in the outside world and how this fear leads to more child-focused consumerism. Parents wanting to keep their children safe often buy toys and gadgets to keep them entertained at home. She also criticizes trends like giving medication to restless children or requiring kids to wear goggles during traditional playground games. While I am unsure how common these strict rules are, Griffiths expresses her frustration with great passion, and she also inspires readers to think about childhood freedoms and rules, from fairy tales to school regulations. 

However, Griffiths sometimes goes too far with her ideas, ignoring important counter-arguments. At one point, she even compares the treatment of children today to a subtle form of racism, calling it ‘really ugly.’ Part of the issue is that Griffiths has a romantic view of children. Although she acknowledges that ‘children can be mischievous,’ she mostly presents an idealized view of them that may not match reality, especially when dealing with a lively group of young children. It would be hard to convince an average parent that, as Griffiths says, ‘children are the musicians of thought.’ Perhaps they could be if given the chance, but I have my doubts. 

One of the main ideas in the book is that children should have the freedom to explore, take risks, and learn from their experiences. Griffiths believes that children need to face some danger to learn how to manage risks. She writes, ‘Children need accidents,’ suggesting that small accidents help them avoid bigger ones later. However, she does not explain how we can create these small accidents safely. Also, do all children really want the ‘wild’ experiences Griffiths admires? What about those who are naturally shy, prefer to stay home, or are more cautious? Perhaps the real issue is that we try to make all children fit into the same mold, whether by keeping them too safe or pushing them too far.'

I am a research bio-psychologist with a PhD, which means I have studied a lot. I am good at solving problems in my work and life, but this skill is not just from my education. Many life problems cannot be solved with complicated formulas or memorized answers learned in school. They need judgment, wisdom, and creativity that come from life experiences. For children, these experiences happen during play. 

My recent research focuses on the importance of play for children's development. All mammals, including humans, play when they are young, and those that need to learn the most play the most.
