However, she appreciates a book called How Not to Write a Novel. "It explains that if the reader starts to guess what will happen, the suspense is likely gone."

It might be easy to say that Charlotte’s parents, both journalists, played a key role in getting her novel published. In fact, her father’s connection in publishing helped get her book read initially. She recognizes her good luck, as it is difficult for anyone to get a first novel read, regardless of their age. "Every aspiring writer needs support and a bit of luck, but after that, you’re on your own. Ultimately, writers succeed or fail based on their talent, so I don’t take anything for granted," Charlotte concludes.

Text: "‘Remember, speed is your friend, not your enemy,’ said Gareth, our instructor, as we looked down the ski slope. ‘Now, who wants to go first?’ The group looked nervous. Then one guy, David, who had some experience with freestyle ski-jumping, stepped forward and skied down the slope towards the jump. He hit the ramp quickly and flew upwards, arms waving in the air. Even to our untrained eyes, something seemed wrong. We held our breath. He landed hard, losing both skis, and flipped head-first into the snow. ‘Remember,’ Gareth kindly told us, ‘speed can be unpredictable.’ Maybe I wasn’t meant for this freestyle skiing. On past skiing holidays, I had enjoyed practicing turns in the snow. I wasn’t one of those teenagers who did freestyle tricks in skate parks. I thought it looked fun, but I felt that if I tried to join the skateboarders, I would be laughed at. Then my parents decided we would have a winter holiday at a freestyle skiing training center in the US. It had a large indoor area near the slopes, with trampolines and ski jumps covered in artificial snow, where students practiced their tricks and landed in foam pits – not a realistic start to what awaited us on the slopes. After practicing indoors, students went outside to try their moves for real. ‘Progression is inevitable!’ the center’s slogan cheerfully promised. ‘Before places like this trained people, inexperienced ski jumpers would just go down the slopes and hope for the best,’ said Gareth. ‘But remember – if you land on the knuckle, you’ll be in trouble.’ The ‘knuckle’ is the flat area behind the jump before the slope becomes the landing zone. If you land in the zone, you keep moving forward, which reduces impact. If you land on the flat, you stop suddenly, which hurts. So, speed is important. At first, it was hard to convince my body to ignore what my brain was telling me and to go straight towards the jump. My legs would almost go backward as I neared the launch point, so I landed hard on the knuckle. I didn’t fall, but by midday I felt exhausted. ‘You need to control the jump, not let it control you,’ said Gareth. Day two began on the trampolines. I thought I would hate being indoors, looking at the snowy mountains outside, but bouncing on the trampolines was fun. Some drills copied moves we would make while ski-jumping, while others taught ‘aerial awareness’ – knowing what your body was doing as you spun in the air. Gareth provided a running commentary. My ‘aerial awareness’ needed improvement – every time I tried, I was aware of the moment before take-off, and then I found myself lying in the foam cubes next to the trampoline. We returned to the mountain to try again. There were more challenges before I finally landed correctly. Gareth seemed as happy as I was, and for a moment, I felt proud of achieving such a difficult goal. But that feeling didn’t last long. On the last run of the day, I forced myself to keep my speed up as I approached the jump, became airborne, and landed correctly in the landing zone. Then I noticed both skis sliding down the slope ahead, no longer attached to my feet."

Text: 'Imagine you are on a rollercoaster at an amusement park. Your palms are sweaty with fear, and your nails are digging into the safety harness. Suddenly, the ride stops, and you take a deep breath as the carriage slowly moves upwards. There is a pause, then a sudden drop that makes your stomach feel weightless. With your teeth clenched, you rush forward, turn sharply to the left, and then go upside down. Your senses are overwhelmed, and you let out a scream of fear. But you chose to be here, just like millions of others who pay to enter theme parks each year. 

What surprises me is that amusement parks, with their thrilling rides designed to attract crowds, are a massive industry. To create the excitement and escape from reality that visitors want, there are large teams of creative engineers and designers working behind the scenes. The idea of being a 'rollercoaster designer' might sound like a childhood dream, but it is actually a challenging job. Designers must find the right mix of fun and fear while keeping passengers safe, and they also need to introduce new ideas to keep visitors interested. 

While many people think rollercoasters have become more extreme, most of the techniques used today, like the wheels that allow rides to go upside down, were invented by American designer John Miller in the early 1900s. During his time, there were fewer safety regulations, and some rides were quite uncomfortable for passengers. Now, designers must work within the limits set by specialized ride manufacturers. 

I spoke to three experts about rollercoasters. Professor Brendan Walker, a 'thrill engineer' with a background in aeronautics, said, 'The skill is in putting the pieces together.' Dr. John Roberts, a member of the Royal Academy of Engineering, explained that this means quickly alternating between feelings of excitement and safety, so riders feel thrilled but not unsafe. 

To create an amazing ride, the teams behind rollercoasters must develop a strong story, whether it’s a space adventure or a jungle chase, that combines with new features like the tallest drops or the most twists to create a smooth experience. However, Professor Walker noted that, like in many creative fields, intuition, experience, and trial-and-error are crucial. Jeff Hornick, a senior director of theme park development, added that it helps to be passionate about thrills to understand what riders want and to test the rides before they open to the public. 

I asked the experts if rollercoaster designers would need to use new technologies like virtual reality. Walker responded that while virtual reality can enhance the experience, it is not a replacement for the physical thrill of the ride. He believes that the real rollercoaster experience will continue to be the main attraction for many years.'

At 25, Miranda Ellington has already accomplished a lot as a choreographer, creating works for many theatres and dance companies. She also dances occasionally. I wonder why she manages to do both activities in her busy life. “Dancing again reminds me of what it’s like to be in the studio, following the instructions of demanding choreographers, and how stressful that can be. Choreographers can forget what it’s like to rehearse all day,” she explains. As a choreographer, she teaches and enjoys working with young students. “A beginner dancer is often open to trying new ideas. In some ways, working with students is easier than with professionals because they are willing to take risks. They want to succeed, but they don’t yet fully understand their strengths and weaknesses. This lack of clarity helps them accept even tough criticism. They might challenge me sometimes, but I appreciate their honest feedback.” 

When Miranda starts with a new group, she focuses on the dance steps, and the music guides her actions. “There may be music I don’t like, but I still create the best dance routine for it. If dancers don’t respond well to a certain composer’s music, it can be frustrating, but I must find solutions. I won’t go back and choose a new piece. Ideally, I’d like to experiment more and have the option to switch music – it would definitely help improve the mood during tough rehearsals. Unfortunately, I’m often working on large productions where the music is already decided by the composer and cannot be changed.” 

Miranda does not want to be tied to one institution. “I think it’s important to keep meeting new people. However, I must remember that the theatres and schools I work with have very different methods and styles. So, I need to adapt my approach each time I go somewhere new, rather than just repeat what I usually do. This helps me avoid becoming too set in my ways.” 

The conversation shifts to a recent documentary about professional ballet dancers and choreographers. “There have been glamorous documentaries in the past that were misleading,” Miranda says. “This one tries to show an accurate picture of life in a dance company. There’s a scene where a young dancer receives many corrections, and I smiled in recognition. She knows she’s not getting it right but can’t make her body do what’s needed. It’s hard to watch but very real. The public often underestimates the amount of work and dedication required in ballet.” 

I ask Miranda what makes a great ballet or dance production. “It’s when everything the company has put in – the music, costumes, lighting, and dancers – comes together. Perfection may be too much to expect, but aiming high is appreciated by audiences and allows for a few mistakes. I’ve been part of productions where the dance steps are excellent, but something about the costumes or props is distracting. That’s disappointing.” 

Miranda has done a wide range of work, so I wonder how she sees herself: is she a modern dance choreographer or a ballet specialist? “People want to label you, and I don’t quite understand that. There’s also a modern trend to focus on developing expertise in a narrow area. I don’t follow that, but maybe one day I’ll be happy to be known for one thing. For now, I just want to broaden my horizons.”

Text: 'A friend once asked me why I travel when I can see everything on television. I agreed that you can see amazing things on TV, but why stay at home on your sofa when there is so much to experience outside? This conversation inspired my unusual four-day trip and a film that encourages people to turn off their TVs. A friend was giving away his old sofa, which became the main focus of the film. I added three wheels and some cables to it and attached them to old seatbelts over my shoulders. I placed my luggage on the sofa and slept on it each night, including one night on the beach. Several friends joined me, helping to pull the sofa and motivating me to keep going. I have gone on many walking trips in recent years, but this was something completely different. It was the longest distance I have ever walked, and I walked on main roads, which allowed me to stop at a café and relax on the sofa with a cappuccino instead of eating sandwiches on a rock. I often told people, “No, I’m not doing this for charity, and I’m not training for a marathon.” When someone at work asks about my weekend, I prefer to share how I dragged a sofa 100 miles across southern England rather than talk about the latest TV show. You can watch the film on my website.'

Text: 'When I read about guided swimming trips in the sea around some small Greek islands, I felt excited. I had never tried organized group trips before. My brother, who I had traveled with before, was busy, so I thought a group holiday might be good for me. The man at the Greek port looked curious when I asked for a single ferry ticket, as the islands are popular with families. I explained that I would not be alone for long; I would be joining ten others to swim around the small islands. Although he still looked puzzled, he smiled and showed me on board. Our group had exchanged emails before we left, but there was little time to talk before our first group swim. Our guides explained that a support boat would follow us the whole time and made sure we knew how to communicate with it. We did a short swim to divide us into speed groups, then it was time for our first proper 1.5 km swim, and I felt nervous. I had trained in my local pool and done some river swimming, but I had never swum long distances in the open sea. Soon, the waves got bigger, and I found myself at the back of the slow group, which was not where I wanted to be. I watched the faster swimmers move ahead like dolphins. I wanted to finish this first distance, though, and I was happy when I finally did it on my own. The next days followed a routine: jumping in, finding a comfortable speed, and stopping to enjoy the scenery. As the swims became longer, so did my speed and enjoyment in completing them. I felt less need for the support boat. I can hardly wait to come back next year.'

Text: "Being a flight attendant is not easy, but since I started this job, I have traveled to many places, from the US to Australia. I work with amazing people, have plenty of time off, and my life is always interesting, which makes it a great job for someone young like me! As a child, I went to a boarding school far from my family, so I always flew alone at the beginning and end of each term. When I felt lonely, I would ask the flight attendants if I could help serve meals to passengers, and some of them let me. This experience stayed with me when I wanted to leave my banking job and look for a new path. At the interview, there were many young people, and many were hired. They were often well-qualified like me and were changing careers. Before the interview, I practiced what to say, focusing on my strengths and past work experience, rather than just saying I loved to travel, which everyone else would say. This approach helped me get the job! I would recommend this kind of work to anyone because there are many rewarding aspects, though the free flights are not the main reason. Most airline staff work very hard, and there is a saying: 'no one is finished until everyone is finished.' It feels like a big family; even if we don’t see each other often, we are still close. When I’m not working, I don’t have to take work home. If I do encounter difficult passengers, which is rare, I know the flight will end soon, and I probably won’t see them again!"

Text: 'At the summer camp where I work, I enjoy watching the children succeed at activities they never thought they could do. Most of the children already know how to swim and play table tennis before they arrive, but rock climbing is a new experience for many of them. Some children feel nervous, but with encouragement, they agree to try, and they all reach the top eventually. This makes them feel proud. 

At the start of the week, some children miss home. It is not the youngest ones who feel this way the most; it is usually the ten- to thirteen-year-olds. We do not allow them to use their mobile phones all the time. First, we tell them they can call home after lunch. When they ask again, usually after dinner, we say it is too late to call now and suggest they do it tomorrow. Most children feel better in a couple of days, and by the end of their week, they come to us to thank us for a great time.

Sometimes, it is not just the children who feel lonely. We also have parents who call frequently to ask how their child is doing, which is often unnecessary. Their child might be busy playing games or doing other activities, so we have to ask the parents to call back later. We often see a certain type of child who comes to camp, usually dressed in expensive new clothes. These children often argue when we ask them to change into something more appropriate, but soon they understand why it is necessary.'

Text: 'Rock the Planet is a musical show where the actors also need to be good musicians. It opened in London last year after five years in the USA, where it won the title of ‘Best Musical’ four times! However, putting on the show with an all-British cast was difficult. The UK has stricter rules about how many performances young actors can do each week compared to the USA, where they can perform more often. Because of this, they needed twice as many actors in the UK. Fortunately, the director found many talented actors based in the UK, and they have just won their first ‘Best Musical’ award. 

The theatre in London is larger than the one in the USA, and it has been full every night, with many people wanting to hear the songs that became popular in America. I met Jamie, an 11-year-old actor in the show. He said, ‘It’s amazing that I get paid to play, especially with a beautiful and expensive Gibson guitar.’ He shared how busy the young actors are. ‘We have regular school lessons each day at the theatre. The teacher is great, but I miss my old school friends.’ 

What do his friends think of the show? ‘Well, my whole class came! The theatre offers special ticket deals for schools. They loved it, which made me feel really confident. My parents come when they can, but it’s expensive for them,’ he explained. When I mentioned that I also play guitar, Jamie found a spare one and invited me to play with him and the other young actors. We played a song called Days, which I didn’t know. Jamie helped me learn it, and I felt proud when I finally got it right. I was impressed by Jamie’s talent and wished I had similar skills. I was just trying to keep up and was relieved that the show’s director wasn’t there to hear my mistakes! 

Although the young actors were already musicians, with some playing several instruments, none had played in a band before. Luckily, they found it quite easy. Jamie said that the hardest part was looking natural when they first performed together. They were so focused that they forgot to smile! The show will be in London for another year, and it is definitely worth seeing.'
